one_reviews_text: This will be thorough and I will cover everything I can.This is a great console, don't get me wrong. It has changed my life. However, oculus makes this with the cheapest possible materials. When a replaceable part breaks, they want it shipped back and you have to handle that yourself. Estimated ship time was a month To, not round trip. I told them no. The bracket at the top of the goggles that you feed the strap through, broke off entirety. It's flexible plastic. A joke. I ordered a 3d printed replacement and will be fixing it myself. Meanwhile, I use doubled over duct tape for a top strap, to get in my daily work outs and play with friends. Be prepared to spend money on accessories, as there are alot of bad things about them. Not only are the brackets for the straps prone to breaking, so us their brand replacement strap( elite strap). The stock strap holds none of the weight, and gets uncomfortable within 5 mins. I bought a 3rd party ratchet strap, way more comfortable, and lasts me hours of use at a time. The facial padding, is terrible and there is a recall on it. So they include a silicone cover for the material, instead of a new model facial interface, lazy AF. I replaced that with a VR over brand facial interface. They come with loads of extras. 2 pad thicknesses, which are removable to be replaced, sanitary covers that are disposable etc. There is also some mix up within the community on what batteries to use. So most people buy the charge base, from Anker which is an oculus official recommendation. Don't, they overheat and can catch controllers on fire. The batteries that come in the controllers, are nimh 1.5v single use high output batteries. Most rechargeable batteries are only 1.2v, and will /sometimes/ causing response and tracking issues. If you have more then enough light sources, it won't be noticeable. If you have average lighting, you may have issues. There are lights, IR, in the controllers to track them in the headset, so they drain alot on the battery. I would recommend 1.5v lithium ion rechargeable AAs from tenavolt.Pros: Loads of games. Including workout options.Good for it's price, capable.You can also tour world locations, and concerts when they are streamed.Watch TV and movies with certain apps (Netflix, YouTube, big screen, etc)Facebook integrated, for social reasons, that's handy.Not nearly as Intimidating as people seem to think VR is. Most games are rated by standing/sitting/ or roomscale and how intense motion sickness "could" be.Ability to adjust eye spacing.Best entry level to Vr based on price and capabilitiesRefund policy on apps is great. If you have less then 2 hours of use time, and Haven't owned the app longer then 7 days. You can refund right from the phone/PC app, no questions asked.Safety features for play space and object detection. Until you're used to surroundings I suggest using all guardian features. Boundaries, guardian, and space sense. It will show a wall of your play space in VR to stop you from going out of bounds. Space sense projects outlines of objects and people when glancing around you, and within a few feet. Passthrough is also useful. Double tap a finger on either side of goggles, to turn on night vision external cameras to see Through the goggles.In app calorie and movement tracking for fitness. Heads up display overpay in games allow you to track fitness daily goals, while playing with the Oculus Move app. Can be intrusive in some games with extreme up or down glances.Cons:Battery life is short. As low as 1 hour for large-scale games like MMOs, as long as 3-4 hours for single player games, but rarely.Needs accessories to be user friendlyUncomfortable strapWeak parts, prone to breaking. (my unit is 2 months old and broke)Controller battery confusing. 1.5v single use nimh or 1.5v continuous lithium ion rechargeable AA, per controller.Recommended charge base, NOT SAFE. Mine constantly overheated within minutes of charging.Oculus official accessories are stupid expensive. 80-90$ for a cable for charging/PC connectionSupport is terrible /Facebook/There IS an adjustment period. Can cause disoriented sensations and motion sickness. Start out with short sessions, multiple times throughout the day/per week to adequately adjust. Takes time. I have vertigo issues and I manag d to adjust within a few weeks. First week was terrible, but fun.Passthrough safety function can accidentally be turned on, his which temporarily turns game off. Adjusting headset fit will register as double tapping. Recommended to turn it off, with experience level. There is a shortcut on the popup menu.

Why would I use a quest when I have an Index? Because my index has a big cable sticking out of the back, and if I get sweaty, the comfortable foam around the headpiece and face mask sucks up all my sweat and seals it in. I don't want a stanky headset.The quest comes with a silicon gasket that goes over the foam. It doesn't feel great at first but you get used to it. And the first time you get sweaty doing a VR work out, and find you can clean the sweat with a napkin and it just wipes off that silicone, you will understand why it's superior to fabric or foam. It's super easy to keep clean. So you can go ballistic in beatsaber, get 30 min of cardio, and not worry about stinking up your headset.The display is also really good, seems higher resolution than my Index, definitely easy to use it as a web browser, watch movies, etc.The on board audio is nowhere near as good as real headphones or the Index audio, but its perfectly adequate for gaming, although you do have to crank the volume to 100%. Also, at high volume, bass tends to move air near your temples, which tickles. You'll be playing beat saber and suddenly feel like a bug is crawling on your forehead when the bass drops.The strap it comes with is trash. Throw it away the first chance you get and buy the elite strap with battery.The power cable it comes with is too short to use while playing.The controllers are comfortable and feel better than the Reverb G2's larger and more plasticy feeling ones. As a bonus, they only use 1 AA battery and I get WEEKS of battery life with daily use. My Reverb G2 goes through 2 AA's in a single long play session and I get at most a few days of use out of it. It also doesn't like rechargables and wants alkalines so it gets $$$. The quest controllers last forever on 1 battery.The experimental features really make the Quest fun. The hand tracking works really well, allowing you to use the headset on a bus, plane, or in public without breaking out the controllers. You won't be gaming with it, but you can browse the web and watch movies without the need for controllers.The pass through video is as good as the Valve Index except it's in black and white only. But you get a very natural feeling 3d video experience that allows you to double tap the headset, and instantly see your room with natural 3d depth perception. I can walk around the house with the headset on and not worry about hitting stuff.The quest versions of popular games are graphically simpler than steam versions, and you have to buy games you already own a 2nd time, but it's worth it for the un-cabled awesome that is the VR exercise regimen.Get an hour of cardio a day and not feel like you're working out. Quest will keep your brain and your body younger longer.
review_title: I have a Valve Index, and I still spend 50% of my VR gaming in the Quest. It's that useful and fun.

one_reviews_text: FIVE MINUTES after setup, I get an email that my accounts been suspended. Are you serious? How does that even happen? I now have a useless paperweight, and Oculus and Facebook support have been completely useless. Thanks Facebook.

I had a bit of trouble setting it up to work with SteamVR, but eventually, I figured it outMore specifically, I didn't understand at first how the main Oculus interface and the Oculus desktop app are correlated with each other; only then I discovered that I had to get the Virtual Desktop app from the Oculus store on the main interface, not through the desktop appI also put on the silicon thing for the face, and while it helps quite a bit, it's not perfect; sometimes the headset just pushes against the nose a little too much, so I have to adjust itOverall, the price for wireless SteamVR gaming is well worth it!EDIT Oct 12, 2021Eventually, I figured out how to play SteamVR games over Oculus Link/Air Link: after enabling the feature (in the desktop app under Beta and in the headset under Experimental), you need to add each game manually via the desktop app, and then in the headset, from within the Link interface, go to Library, making sure to show in the filter Unknown Sources, and your game(s) will appear thereHowever, keep in mind that some games will take some trial and error to adapt for accurate tracking (for me, it was Rick and Morty: Virtual Rick-ality)

So far so good.  The quality feels great in my hands.  The leather seems supple but firm.  The plastic component, although the time of the white is ever so slightly off from the headset.  Somewhat of a Greyish tint but i wood have never noticed it except I’m trying to be critical of this product.  I paid for this with my own $, no inducement of any sort.  Worth trying out.  Also I have not tried the official elite strap but the greater padding of this strap appealed to me so I bought this one instead.

Yes people, it's once again that time of year where we are all eating celery, drinking water and using our gym memberships and dusty exercise bikes! We also have an older X-Box 360 Kinect, which we use for Zumba, Dance and other games that really help you work up a sweat. Between weights, treadmill, elliptical and the X-Box we feel like we have plenty of options to keep us working out 3-4 times a week until we give up in April! (let's be realistic).Anyhow, the X-box is getting a little finicky so we decided to look for a newer model. Sure, you can get the X-Box One, which is now a generation old, with the Kinect camera, but Microsoft isn't offering the Kinect option with the newer X-Box X. I saw an Oculus commercial and decided to do some research.After looking at the 3-4 popular VR options, the Quest seemed like the no-brainer. There is PS-VR, which requires a PS5 (good luck finding one, and by itself it's 2x the price of the Quest 2) and you still have to buy the PS VR headset itself. Interestingly enough it works with a camera on the PS5 that looks similar to the Kinect camera. There are other VR headsets out there that are rated highly, and may have more gaming power and resolution, but they are 3-4x as expensive as the Quest 2.So I bought a Quest 2, some important accessories (Anker charging station, silicone cover for the foam face cover, and an upgraded headset with integrated extended life battery) and started surfing.First of all, if you think VR is cheesy or not-enveloping, poke around and look at "Conquer Your Fear of Heights" or "Shark Attack". Your eyes can really fool the rest of your body when you're in VR! Second, the games on this are lightning quick with accurate representation of your movements in real time. You can watch YouTube or Amazon Prime VR programming, surf the web, and find all sorts of neat VR stuff through the headset.After demoing some games and poking around, I decided to purchase Beat Saber. I know, this is not a 'deep cut' but within 20 minutes I was addicted. Who knew cutting neon boxes to the sounds of electronica would be so fun??Skeptical you can get a good workout in VR? Go to volume 3 or 4 or the extras section of Beat Saber and do 20 minutes. Within 20 minutes I'm sweating (that's why you get the silicone protector) heart was beating 110 BPM and my Apple Watch recorded a dance workout where I burned 350 calories and got 3400 steps. If you set the difficulty higher (from Easy to Normal, for instance) it's like running faster on a treadmill; you get a better workout because you're just chopping away at boxes, dodging walls, ducking, and at times you feel like a rock drummer as you crash boxes to the rhythm of those electronic beats.Would I use this as my only exercise option? Probably not, but does it feel like I'm trudging away on a treadmill, just waiting for it to be over? Not at all! 20-30, even 75 (!) minutes goes by so fast when you're in the zone, just crushing your old high-score.This isn't a Beat Saber review, but just one example of a cool "fitness game" you can play. There is also Dance Central, Audica, and many other enveloping VR options where you really get yourself moving.You can pay a lot of money for fitness equipment or game consoles, so I feel like the $299 I spent on this and the additional $150 of accessories was easily worth the price. Everyone who comes over uses it and loves it so I feel like in 2 weeks we've already got our money's worth from it. You don't NEED the accessories either. We used it for a couple of days with only what came in the box and it was fine. The accessories just make it a bit more convenient and comfortable.

VR is great, i've been doing it since 2016.  I got the first Quest when it came out then the second when it came out.  VR is much more than gaming.  It's just as much educational and social as it is gaming.  I'm old, so to watch video games go from Pong to the VR of today was an incredible journey.Pros,1) It's wireless VR, amazing, great fun and exercise.Cons,1) A Facebook account is required/isn't required, eventually it will be.  The problem isn't so much that an account is required, it what Facebook/Meta does with the information they thoroughly collect about you, me, our friends and relatives, so everybody and how we all relate.2)  Facebook/Meta was never a Operating System company before they bought Oculus.  So you end up with updates that screw things up or take features away.  For example, when the Quest first came out, you had parties and other communication options in VR, but with an update, Facebook took those things away and required a data vacuum account (Facebook).  Another example, the IPD setting got messed up with an update.  I then had an IPD pop up in middle of the gaming view regularly.  There was an adjustment you could make to disable it but required a sidequest hack every time you used the headset.  There is a long thread in a Facebook forum of all the users affected by this but i think Facebook/Meta simply ignored us.3) They stop providing controllers for your headset.  For example, if you own a Quest 1, they stopped selling controllers for it a while back.  If it breaks or wears out, you'r SOL.  Pretty sad they don't support their customers.  They should have a warning to let us know that after you buy the Quest, spare parts will only be available for a limited time.  You currently can't replace a Quest 2 controller.  Controllers break, things happen.  If Facebook/Meta isn't going to allow third parties to develop controllers then Facebook/Meta needs to keep offering them for people who invest into Facebook's products.  We all don't have Zuckerberg money, some of us scrape to get our hands on a headset.  Mark might want everybody buying a headset every two years, but many people can't afford that.I've come to the conclusion that Facebook is all about collecting our data and the Quest is a tool to accomplish that goal.  I don't believe that they are serious about VR.  They bought VR, they didn't develop it.  The day another company comes out with a decent wireless VR headset, i can't buy it fast enough.I rate VR 5 stars, Oculus developed something amazing.I rate Facebook's/Meta's implementation/purchase of it, 2 stars
Amazing

I am an FPV Drone Racing Pilot, not many know what that is, but some will, I got into it and got out of gaming, just didnt see anything in games that compare to flying until one day when a friend of mine got one of these and brought it over to my house.. WOW, When I put it on I knew I had to buy one..... and here is my review one month later...Pro's - This has so much potential, it is a lot of fun and very immersive, many things to do with youtube and other programs that make the free part of it great.. The games are not bad priced and seem to be pretty good for the most part, plenty of titles and more coming out is great. The daily deals and things like that make the games even more affordable..Con's - OK, so lets start with the size, it is a bit large and a little heavy, I do understand that most of the weight is the lenses, they are pretty heavy due to how they are made, but no OLED screens for a box like this was I think a mistake, with that type of resolution even the older games would look better and a lot more clear for what their lens does. It's glitchy, and I mean glitchy, the first one I got had a sound issue and I could no longer communicate with others on the oculus, so I turned it in and they sent another one..  But this one has many glitches as it just will go out without warning and not come back on, then I wait for a moment and it will start up again and I can play.. but many games crash and the system crashes on a pretty regular basis, now I do play a lot so? but shouldnt matter, that should be the goal.. Battery life, now this is for not only gaming but for watching movies, hanging out with friends, and trolling in a social environment, which means that you will most likely wear this thing for hours.. battery lasts about 2 and half hours of constant use.. I bought a 10 thousand MaH battery to strap to the back and it works really well, but ads quite a bit of weight to the headset. With the lipo tech these days, they should have a battery that lasts at least 8 hours.. The battery I bought lasts about 8 to 10 hours of use. They need to come out with the super deluxe bundle package.. Many things you will want to get pretty quick... The battery, extra headset, the one they offer is not bad, but was really spendy and I got an aftermarket one for quarter the cost. carry case that will accommodate the extra large heads trap.FINAL THOUGHT - Buy or no? Well I do have fun with it, I find myself in it quite a bit, but I see the games getting bigger and bigger, the size of the memory is not even close to what it should be, so I got the 256, which I will be out of room soon.. I would also suggest getting the extra strap and battery as well right off the bat.. you will run out of power getting it set up then you will want to explore but wont have the power.I would say its a good buy at 300 bucks and not bad at 400.. but much more improvements will hopefully be coming ..I will recommend this product as it is fun, immersive and will eventually be what everyone is doing.

I know by the title you think I am under the wrong product for review, but I’m not. I am reviewing the Oculus Quest 2 VR headset. I started using my sons oculus when he went away to his dad‘s house for Christmas and got addicted to beat saber. I loved it so much that I didn’t want to give his headset back when he got home so I had to buy my own. I play at least an hour of beat saber every single day and I have lost almost 24 pounds since. This is the most fun I’ve had working out ever. I don’t even realize that I’m burning so many calories because I’m having so much fun. I love that you can play online with other people and compete against them.I also bought the Walk Around mini golf game which is really fun and nice and relaxing except for when they drop you on top of the cliff. It really does feel like you’re standing on top of a cliff which can be a little unnerving at first.I think the only complaint that I have is the strap for the headset. It’s very difficult to keep this on your head unless you have a ponytail you can tuck under the strap to make it tighter. I ended up buying an elite strap for my son and I and while I didn’t like having to shell out the extra money so that we could actually play with the VR headsets, it’s still worth it.
review_title: This is the best home gym I have ever bought.

one_reviews_text: So turds at Facebook....these VR goggles are rated for ages 13+ but you have to be 18 to have a Face Book account which is a must to use these goggles.

My friend gave me a taste of this VR headset. I said why not? I was hooked when I got that taste. So I decided to buy the 256GB with the elite headset and bag for over 500$. Which wasnt a bad deal.  When I got the device first thing I noticed was a hiccup in synching my phone mobile app to utilize the device but after some troubshooting i was able to get it to connect. Though synching with my mobile was an issue. Another problem I notice was the battery life. It drains the battery very fast which is about 2 hours.  Other problems was connecting to PC i wish the USB cord allowed me to connect to my PC to transfer files. I had to use google drive to upload and download files. When I watch movies my controllers would make a grid which interferes with movie experience. 4K VR movies comes out grainy. Resolution is not so great. Which is kind of disappointing. Hopefully they would make better improvements. After 2 weeks of owning this device the battery will not charge anymore. So i have to return it.  The only good thing is the controls are responsive and easy to use interface.  I am waiting for Occulus 3 to make improvements. This is not a good product.

I got my order super fast.  Literally about 24 hours. When I got it I went to set it up and noticed the serial number was Different than what was printed on the box. When looking through the lenses on the right hand side there was what looked like a blue ribbon About an inch long that wouldn’t go away. I was also not able to set it up I couldn’t get past the five digit code screen even though it said my quest was registered an active. Was sent back I got the new one today and will try it when I get home.EDIT:  I got my new quest and what a difference. The box was actually shrink wrapped unlike the other box I got that was not.  the serial numbers also matched. Are use the new quest for about 30 minutes and it was awesome. But I’m leaving this review at one star because they sent me a returned product that didn’t work. I suggest you go to Best Buy or some other store  to buy this and not Amazon. I will be rethinking how I order things.
review_title: Serial order on the quest did not match the serial  order on the box.

one_reviews_text: This thing has changed my life.. I'll let you know later if it was for the better or worse. I've had so much fun in the virtual world that I've checked out of the real one. I'm ditching friends for dinner and meeting virtual friends online for fun and games. LOL... I can go anywhere with the push of a button. Just imagine the savings in airfare alone. I went to Dubai last night and was blown away. WOWZA

I like the oculus because it's a viral realty system that puts you in places you have never been before and always wanted to go. Yes if you like traveling you can travel to any state or country. You can go to places you always been dreaming about going.  And you can play tennis, bowl, golf, exercise travel etc. play with your friends. I have been around the world with the oculus, and enjoyed every minute of it and every trip.  Theres so much more you can do. Yes I recommend it for any one who can keep in mind that it just VIRTUAL REALITY ONLY. And i stress that because everything you do, makes you feel like your actually doing it.  If you love roller coasters you don't have to leave your home to get the thrill. But keep in mind you could get Dizzy. And you do feel the sensation of riding. Also if you love animals you can see them up close.
review_title: This is for people who don't lose theirselves in the reality world.

one_reviews_text: Now that Ive gotten 50 hrs or so in, across a few apps and games I feel comfortable in reviewing this. It works great and really brings you to another world when it goes smooth. That being said it does have charging while playing issues not related to your PC do some research problems are more than a year old and Oculus responds with they are aware and working on it. Apparently at a snails pace but at least they acknowledge it. I wont suggest one product over another but a few solutions are available and can be bought on Amazon and elsewhere to remedy it until they get around to figuring it out. This is a quick changing and newish tech so its fair to say there will be growing pains. As far as wireless it works great I also got the elite strap with additional battery this is a must, a little pricey but changed the entire feel and use of the headset! Again many other choices at lower price but I find you get what you pay for as I tried to cheap out on 2 diffrent Link cables to PC and just wound up retrurning and buying over priced Oculus brand cable but you know what it hasnt failed since so I guess I got what I paid for regardless of my feelings on pricing. This can be a really cool learning tool, entertainment tool and even a productive tool the applications I can imagine will be limitless one day. As of today I stil hate the costs associated and it took me awehile to save and convince myself to buy it my only regret is I didnt do it sooner. If your not tech savy or dont have immediate access to someone that is I would avoid this for now, but if your patient and willing to learn a bit and do some research from time to time you will really enjoy this. Just pace yourself and build a tolerance as it can be disorienting and vomit inducing at times took me a good week to be able to stay on a couple hours without side effects LOL
review_title: I love it but it does have a few issues

one_reviews_text: Bought this to play pc vr games on, it my first headset and was somewhat hesitant since it was technically a standalone unit. Waited for a while and watched reviews on it and finally splurged and purchased it. Just in the main "room" I was in awe. Played the tutorial and was in awe... Once I played some pc vr I was in a whole another world. I have been playing it with the air link and have had no issues with it. First title I played was Hellblade: Senua's Sacrafice because I already had it and it was already an amazing game on just the monitor. Hooooollly crap! I was not expecting it to be that much more amazing it in vr! Bought more pc vr games since then and have not been disappointed! Most recent was Half-Life: Alyx and so far seems extraordinary! I highly recommend this headset. Only downside is Facebook.

The Quest2 is acceptable for its price. Although you will have to spend quite a bit extra for a link cable, a headstrap upgrade, some nice earbuds/headphones, and so on. The controllers are surprisingly good, but nowhere near as good as the Valve Index "Knuckles" Controllers. The Quest2 will not give you the ultimate experience, but it will get you into VRchat or Beat Saber on a budget.Normally, I'd give this headset around a 4/5, but there's 1 little issue. You must have a Facebook account, and you must link your Quest2 to your smartphone. You have to hand over basically all of your personal information just to use the thing, and currently there's no method to completely avoid this process. It's a massive violation of privacy, and unacceptable for a piece of hardware to require from its users.Yes, you can give false information, but you risk getting banned and unable to use your headset anymore. Yes, there are ways to deal with all of this, but you must be very tech-savvy and be willing to invest hours into setting things up - and even then, there's always the chance of a stealth update ruining your whole set-up.So yes, it's a decent headset, but even if it was literally free I would be hesitant to recommend it to anyone because of the Facebook integration.
review_title: Decent Headset, but Facebook-Integration is a Nightmare

one_reviews_text: It's a fun all in one VR but it's not a big jump from the Go version like you would think. It's worth buying for gaming but if you just like to watch VR and not a big gamer then I would just buy the Go. The PQ is not alot better and you would only notice if you side by side the quest2 and Go to see it. Sound hands down is better on the Go it has more of a surround FX and is clearer in sound over all then the quest 2 only thing quest 2 has over the Go in sound it has way more bass. Some apps I like on the Go are not on the quest 2 which I see as dumb because you would understand if the Go could not play quest 2 apps then okay because you would think the Go does not have the better video card,processor or whatever but for the quest 2 not to have Go apps you had before is just dumb and shows lack of backwards compatible from oculus. I was very dispointed with the Oculus quest 2 out of the box because I was thinking it was going to be blowing the Oculus Go out of the water in every which way but it does not. Onces your over the dispointment like I was it's not bad the quest 2 if you look at it as it's just different then the Go and not as better. Quest 2 you need to change refresh rate to 120hz in setting and you can get a third party app to help changes more setting to make the quest 2 have a better PQ so keep that in mine you can YouTube all that if you want to know more. I don't like some things on the quest 2 seem like a down grade from the Go version like Sound,there no sound volume numbers anymore like 1 to 15 on the Go,there no display brightness anymore,the power and sound buttons in a different location then the Go and there not in a better spot I think,even the charging light is now in a dumb spot which is on the side of the quest 2 so now you have to pick it up to see if it's charged or tilt your head to see it when on the Go it's right on top of it so boom you can see it a mile away without picking it up it's charged,head strip is more uncomfortable on the quest 2 then the Go out of the box yes you can get a upgraded strip with added battery from Oculus but that extra money. There was just some dumb moves made by Oculus on the quest 2 but not saying there where not go moves made too like the controls there are two they track your hands and you do not need to even uses controls at times because you can track your own hands. The extra cameras on the quest 2 are nice you can tap the side of the Quest 2 to turn them on to see where your going and not have to remove the VR off your face,you can now walk in VR walk and look around more way better then the Go version there. You can adjust your eye lens good move there. Is it super faster then the Go no but it is a faster VR all in one then the Go which still helps in fast moving gaming. So get the quest 2 if you game and play more games then watch VR but if your just a VR watcher like using it to sit in a roller coaster,looking at mountain,look at shows,movies,plays,magic shows and etc..... Just things you sit and watch then buy the Go and save lots of money you do not need the quest 2.

I am an avid gamer and was drawn in to VR after a buddy told me about the Occy Quest 2. Right away I can say there is a lot of value here for $299. Unlike other VR systems, you don't need a computer or anything to use this. You just need an internet connection to install some games. There is also a lot of free content and demos that can be enjoyed as you start to get a feel for being in a VR environment. So far I have said a lot of positive things so why a 1/5 star review? Here is what you don't realize until after you use a VR headset...This gives you motion sickness. People will argue on the severity but the community of players will collectively agree that this is not something you can just bring with you on a family holiday visit, and strap your uncle, aunt, mom, dad, grandpa, and grandma into without causing them to want to throw up their lunch/dinner after 5min.When I first started thinking about VR, I remembered back to the Nintendo Wii. I put the Nintendo Wii controls into my family members hands and they bowled, played baseball, boxing, etc and thought it was fun. None of them felt like puking afterwards. However I can't replicate that same gimmicky nostalgia that the Nintendo Wii offered us 10 yrs ago with this Occy Quest 2. The VR experience is just too intense for most people. You have to be extremely careful about how you show this to people that have no prior VR experience.If your thought process was, I want the Occy Quest 2 for myself but also to show off to all my family/friends so they think it is the greatest thing since sliced bread, you will likely be tremendously disappointed with the results.If you do have a group of people that you want to show this to that you feel are able to handle it, then this is how I would suggest setting up..Step one is the get into the VR yourself and create a stationary boundary from a seated position. A sturdy chair that someone can sit it while in VR.Next, you will cast your Occy Quest 2 to a TV or laptop so you can spoon feed the VR user step-by-step directions on where to navigate.Next, you will have them get into the VR and launch First Steps for Quest app. This is a simple tutorial with a very calm environment. Easy for a beginner to get comfortable with the controls and try a couple simple VR novelty tricks like picking up and throwing some blocks, paper airplanes, shooting ray guns, etc.Once they are done with this First Steps for Quest, you should encourage them to stop playing. This is usually a tipping point for a new user where their brain is going to start fighting with their stomach and rejecting this VR experience. VR motion sickness is not fun and can last awhile. If you jump on Youtube and look up "VR sadness" or "VR depression" you can hear people talk about the disassociation with reality working in conjunction with their motion sickness that new users experience with VR making them feel like depressed garbage for the rest of the day or even for a day or two. Don't let new users get to this point hahaIf the person insists on wanting more, I would have them check out VR Animations App. You should already have a couple neat saved animations that they can jump into and look at. This is a fun program to showcase the cool little things that VR can offer and it really is a cool visual experience. Be careful to avoid animations that spin, rotate, or give the feeling that the VR user is in motion (example: sitting in or next to a car that is driving down a road).Overall, this is really a neat device. I think VR is going to be around for awhile or some version of it. We are quickly going to see VR headset power and resolution make huge leaps and bounds in the next couple years. I predict that someday soon you will no longer furnish your living room at home with speakers, TVs, big sectional couches, etc. to watch your TV shows and movies. Instead you relax somewhere comfortable and slip on your VR headset and be transported to some massive movie theatre in space, sitting next to popcorn guzzling aliens, and watching some 3D animated movie off of Amazon Prime Video VR or other subscription based service.and as interesting, amazing, or terrifying as this may sound not everyone is going to be able to handle this level of stimulation. So VR wisely! Scale your expectations appropriately! and good luck out there!
review_title: Really Fun HOWEVER be aware of this!!

one_reviews_text: This VR Headset for a birthday gift is turning into an expensive gift I don't have the time or money for. After the headset, you basically need to hell out another 80$ for this cable and then another 10-15$ for an adaptor for the COMPUTER you need to connect it too. Why does it not come with adaptors?Beginning to think if I dig deep enough I will find that Apple owns Oculus and that will explain all of the gadgets and doo-dads I need to buy to get anything to literally work.Will be leaving same review on the stupid 80$ cable had to buy to get it working too

After a week of using the Oculus Quest 2, I allowed my son to play some of the social apps such as Horizon Worlds and Rec Room. Within that day he was suspended for the Horizon Worlds app, and the following morning I woke to find that Oculus had suspended my account for 24 hours.The suspension ‘bricked’ the $300 dollar headset. Even the games I’ve purchased were not available, even if they were solo games which have no social aspect to it. The suspension came after an email was sent to me stating that the account violated the code of conductI will admit that I have one of those kids who can shut up if his life depended on it, and that in social situations he is that bubbly kid who will friend anyone and rattle off about all kinds of kid stuff. This can be considered annoying (I admit it is annoying, and I love my kid unconditionally). I’m certain his behavior found him being reported, and the report resulted in the suspension.Oculus customer support is absolutely horrible. The chat feature simply regurgitated to me what I just told them. Imagine answering a question and then the person trying to answer your question with your answer. That was Santiago G… customer service rep numero uno.So here I sit… with a $300 brick and some fancy hand controllers which do nothing and no explanation can be provided. Needless to say I’m returning this and hoping for a refund. Probably won’t get a single penny on any of the games I purchased. Save your money… get your kid a Nintendo switch.
review_title: If your kids talks to much and might be considered annoying don’t buy this.

one_reviews_text: Product is great, is how Amazon handled their Black Friday promotion of a $50 credit being the reason why this is one star. I added the Oculus too my cart to decide if I wanted to use Amazon or another store (Target and Bestbuy was running the same promotion). I Purchased through Amazon because there were other products I wanted to purchase from Amazon as well.I read on Amazon site that sometimes it takes a few weeks for promotion to apply, which didn’t make much sense but ok, I decided to wait. 2 weeks go by and I reach out for Amazon for support. Basically, “Nicolas” was not any help and basically said since I didn’t do an “Instant Buy”, the promotion did not apply. Honestly, I don’t even remember if I did instant buy or not, because I did remove the Oculus from my cart before changing my mind. Basically, Amazon support is saying that I will not receive the promotion credit when at any time did I read you must do an “Instant Buy” to receive it. I also have a friend who experienced the same issue with Amazon.So the product itself is 5 stars, how Amazon handled the promotional aspect is a 1 star, and I will be returning and contemplating using Amazon for future purchases.

This is better than my PSVR by heads and shoulders.The wireless freedom, the games, the experiences all feel top notch. I am quite pleased. I am in love with Real VR Fishing and Eleven Table Tennis.I removed a star due to a few things. These aren’t big things, but definitely things you need to consider before buying. Most of them mean hidden costs.1. Hidden cost of having to buy a better head strap. Seriously, the one included is very uncomfortable.2. The case this goes in is extra and doesn’t fit my new 3rd party head strap.3. Battery life isn’t great and I will probably need to get a back up battery to make the experiences last longer.4. My wife gets very sick using it, even in stationary games. Glad I tested this out before I got a pair of them.5. The package is very barebones. No controller guards or no rechargeable batteries for the controllers. Crappy head strap. No case or even lease wipe.6. Facebook account. Ughhh. Soon this will be removed, but ughhhh. Facebook is the worst thing ever. -11 stars for this alone.Bottom line—If you want a top notch VR experience without wires and a fancy computer or PlayStation. This is the thing to get. Just be ready to spend a little more to make it a far better experience.

I’m new to VR and had no idea what I’ve been missing! This is unbelievable! The Oculus 2 provides enjoyment for so many of my different interest, I honestly had no idea how useful it would be. If you’re looking to purchase a piece of exercise equipment for daily cardio look no further, the Oculus makes your workout so much fun and time flies by so quickly. It’s not only amazing for physical fitness, the brain gets its share of exercise as well. After a fun filled workout, I typically enjoy some virtual travel and often go chill at some of the most peaceful destinations on earth at the click of a button. On lazy days you can kick back in your recliner and have just as much fun doing a number of different things available on the Oculus as well. The content available is growing at a very rapid rate, I think that no matter what your interests are you’ll find so much to enjoy and will not regret this purchase. I can’t describe how life changing this has been and I honestly feel it has improved my health and quality of life. I could never really get interested in cardio or any type of exercise and stick with it until the Oculus came into my life, my health paid the price and statistics say the same for so many others in this country. Take action and encourage others to do so as well!
review_title: The most enjoyable purchase that I’ve made in quite some time!

one_reviews_text: As you all have done, I did my research and this product was hyped and rated excellently. First off, when I put the headset on, I thought maybe it was broken. The focal point of this is so small everything that isn't exactly a midline is blurry. Text is fuzzy. I tried all of the different focus settings and at the very best it wasn't good. Got on the internet and realized that this is a huge problem with the headset. And there's no fix for it. I said it aside for a day and came back to it and the video wouldn't turn on. It had sound, so I could tell I was on a loading screen, and after I reset, which was recommended, it still didn't turn on. I contacted Oculus and after 30 minutes on a chat session they told me they would get back to me in a few days and let me know what I should do. Very unhappy that there was no immediate fix or any kind of tech support to try something different with it. Apparently a reset is about the only thing you can do. I'll wait a few days to see what happens. Maybe I just got a bad one.
review_title: Blurry, small focal area, died after 2 hours.

one_reviews_text: As you should know already, Facebook is required. While trying to log into Facebook I got stuck in an endless loop of logging in. Oculus support recommended trying a different device so I logged into my computer with Facebook and got completely locked out of my account of 12 years for trying to log into an unrecognized device. So. I have a 300 brick and can't access any of my personal info on Facebook. Thanks, Meta. Don't waste your time or money.

I own a Rift S and wanted a wireless option without breaking the bank , this headset was an upgrade in every way except 1. The Halo Headband on the Rift S is incredibly comfortable and takes 95% of the load off of your neck and back , which allows for longer game sessions. Now while the Quest 2 is great for short 30 minute sessions , it starts to show that the factory strap is severely flawed. I had extreme neck pain after only an hour and a half of playing on the quest 2 and with my Rift S i can easily go for 6+ hours with no discomfort. I suggest buying a 3rd Party "elite" or "halo" strap to fix the issue , as there are plenty available for between $25 - $50 USD on amazon.
review_title: A Great VR Headset. With bad weight distribution

one_reviews_text: To get right to the point, I cannot recommend this device. While it did eventually get set up, there are unneeded hoops to jump through that cause problems both on the technical side and on the trust side.To set up, you are required to have or open a Facebook account. I get that Facebook bought Oculus, so that's where it stems from, but there is no valid technical reason for this requirement. Why is this needed? Simply to boost FB registration numbers? To make a grab for personal info? It does not inspire trust.The second irritating, unnecessary hoop is requiring you to install a mobile device app and to pair the headset. I ran into problems with this which took using a second phone to get it accomplished. Thankfully the household had a second device available to use. Then, once that was finally done it seems unneeded any more since the headset works without doing anything on that paired phone. Tech support told me that my mesh wifi could be the problem. Really? All a mesh wifi does is present a single SSID to devices connecting to it, how can that interfere?Ultimately it did get working, and tech support was responsive, so it gets a second star for that.
review_title: Incredibly Frustrating Setup. Sketchy, unnecessary prerequisites

one_reviews_text: It despise Facebook, but had to create an account just to use this.
review_title: CANT USE UNLESS YOU GIVE FACEBOOK YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION

one_reviews_text: I've had a Facebook account for over 11 years that was previously linked to my Oculus Go around 3 years ago.  I got my Quest a few days ago and when I try to log into the Oculus app with Facebook it just spins.  Customer support said it was a known issue but offered no resolution or a time frame.  From all my login attempts, my Facebook account of 11 years was frozen.  Not worth the hassle for me.  Sorry, Oculus.  You lost a customer.
review_title: Unable to log in to the Oculus app, my Facebook account was frozen

one_reviews_text: We purchased The Oculus Quest 2 256mb for our daughter for Christmas and we have all had so much fun with it as a family. You can play poker with other people and golf as well as watch Netflix and so much more! It’s a must have for your family and I can see the Oculus Quest VR being something that every house having at least one in the near future! It was easy and quick to receive purchasing it on Amazon and i recommend purchasing it on Amazon with their customer service. Thank you so much for making this experience for our family one of the best Christmas’s, we have had so many laughs and fun with this product! 5 stars!!!
review_title: The best item for family in 2022!

one_reviews_text: Fantastic, I had no idea that I could work out inside and burn so many calories. I run, I cycle, but I never burned after a 40 minutes workout. I downloaded Supernatural, the Fitness app, and I burned 640 calories after 30 minutes of workout. I had to squat, punch, and destroy objects and my arms are sore already. I love the oculus and I will subscribe to the Supernatural app with no doubt. It is like having a full gym inside your home.For the Oculus in general, it is great, of course, I could not wear it for a long time because it leaves me heavy marks on my face and scalp but holy darn, I saw myself in a Total Recall movie. The technology is simply amazing and watching videos in 360 is so amazing. I think this has been the best purchase of my last 10 years without a doubt.I would recommend it - Keep in mind if you wear glasses or lenses you will need those or you won't be able to see well on your oculus.Buy it, I am sure you will love it.
review_title: First time I burned 600 calories working out!!!!

one_reviews_text: The controllers feel cheap and the headset moves too much when I shake my head even when tightened. The biggest deal-breaker is that they require Facebook to use it and if you get banned from Facebook you lose everything you purchased. The field of view is also really disappointing as it feels smaller than looking through a telescope. Overall I'm very unhappy with this purchase and would recommend other brands like the Index over this.
review_title: The field of view is too narrow and I despise the mandatory Facebook login.

one_reviews_text: My wife bought me this for xmas - 3 months later its still sitting on a shelf in the kitchen untouched in the factory sealed box and plastic shrink wrap. I just feel disgusted every-time i look at it knowing its past the return date and how much money she wasted on it.Cons:- very little content available- very short battery life- very small community (unless you count foul mouthed 12yos)Pros: its just the right size to block off the edge of the top of the cabinet to stop the cat from jumping up there.

The storage of the Oculus Quest 2, like any gaming console, uses up a healthy chunk of its storage for required software: 11. 3GB, to be exact. Plus, it comes pre-installed with a few demos and First Steps tutorials, but those can be uninstalled if you wish, freeing up a few hundred megabytes. You get a little over 116GB of actual storage with the 128GB Quest 2, while the 256GB Quest 2 has a whopping 245GB left for games storage! Gamers who might want to be future-proof could still consider the 256GB version, but the $399 price makes it less affordable for most. The original Oculus Quest 256GB version didn't make much sense to spend extra money on because original Quest games used to average around 1-2GB in size. These days, the best Quest 2 games now hover around the 8-12GB range for many titles.The Oculus Quest 2 is very cool technology. It is not as cool as the technology in Sword Art Online, but you will not be fighting for your life while being stuck in the game. The headset is a bit on the heavy side but comfortable. The straps are quickly be adjusted front-to-back and side-to-side for the best fit. You can also use a spacer to make extra room for glasses. Most size glasses should fit fine in gear, but oversized frames will not. The hand controls are easy to learn and easy to use. The feedback is excellent, and I have not had trouble with lag. The system as a whole is very responsive. The speakers and microphone are apparent. The OS is very user-friendly, and the system walks you through many tasks when first set up. The audio controls even understand my slurred English. Speakers are built into the headset’s strap supports, offering directional left and right stereo sound. They’re reasonably clear and loud enough to get across your games' drama and directional audio feedback while keeping your ears free to allow you some awareness of your physical surroundings. If you’re playing in a room with a friend, they’ll hear everything going on using the built-in speakers, but there’s also a 3. 5mm jack if you want to connect your headphones for a private session. A decent set of stereo speakers are built into the side arms of the strap and produce immersive positional audio. If you want to be isolated, you can plug a regular set of headphones or earbuds into the headphones socket on the side of the headset, but I liked being able to hear a little bit of the natural world as I played. Definitely worth the purchase!

After enjoying my Oculus Go for the past several years, I decided to upgrade to this thinking my experience would only be improved and was super excited to venture into some of the gaming experiences now that VR has had a few years to mature.Aaaand...I never even made it to the homescreen.  The Quest 2 requires the Oculus app, which then merges into your Facebook account and is necessary in order to pair your headset with the app. Why? Because reasons that's why.  Now, I DID know that going in and was ready to do so.  However, the app never gave me the opportunity.  I got stuck in a literal circle of disclosure and agreement menus and as soon as you clicked "Agree and Continue" it would just bounce you back to the previous agreement or bounce you forward to one depending on where you were in the process.After trying two phones and a computer browser, I contacted customer support.  To their credit, I believe they did everything possible to try and get my headset to work and they were all super courteous.  However, after around a week and a half or so of back and forth, and still having the same exact issue with the app, I gave up.  Everything went back in the box and back to Zuckerberg.And what a shame.  I'm certain that it's probably a really good VR experience for those that the app allows to experience it.  I'm also not being over-ominous in saying "that the app ALLOWS to experience it" either.  Because if the app doesn't work, your $400 headset is useless.  Oh, but guess what, if anything happens to your Facebook account, your $400 headset will also become useless as well.  So would you buy a computer if Microsoft could lock your machine because they don't like your emails?  Would you buy a phone that could be disabled if the provider didn't like what you talked to people about?
review_title: The app wouldn't log into Facebook, making the headset worthless.

one_reviews_text: Don't let anyone tell you the rift or rift s is better than this for PC.. this is the best bang for the buck and the image quality and refresh rate is superior to both the rift and rift s. I haven't had tracking issues once and I've been playing wirelessly via virtual desktop exclusively because airlink kinda sucks.. and the link cable I bought randomly disconnects but virtual desktop works flawlessly and I don't notice any latency, then again I'm playing 3 feet from the router.. the stock headband sucks as many others have mentioned as well as the face pad so I upgraded both. The speakers are okay, they're not as bad as everyone makes them out to be but I will be installing a headphone mod on mine. One issue I have is that sometimes the software will freeze when I try to multi task, responding to a Facebook message while streaming my PC for example but a reboot fixes it.. still annoying though. I can't review the all in one aspect of this headset because I use it exclusively for PC VR
review_title: 10x better than the rift cv1 for PCVR

one_reviews_text: If a dead pixel can completely ruin your experience I cannot recommend getting the Quest 2, and here is why,I've gone through a total of 3 Oculus Quest 2s in just under two weeks, and every one of them has had either a stuck pixel or a dead pixel in one or the other screen right out of the box, which means a permanent dot on your screen, I understand VR is fairly new to the market, and Oculus wants to be the affordable option, and boy is it selling,but with all good things, there is the bad, in my research there is no fix for this but to replace the entire unit and hope you get one without a dead pixel, I tried three times with no luck, so a 1 out of 4 chance is your best odds going with my experience, though chances could be worse, or you could get lucky,That said, amazon support is very friendly and helpful, understanding and willing to work with you, at least in my case, in the end I accepted a partial refund and decided to keep the headset, I think it is possible to live with the dead or stuck pixel, but I would suggest getting the 128GB version over the 256GB, save yourself the money, your likely to use steam anyways,If you decide to roll the dice and want to try what I did, getting a headset without a dead or stuck pixel, this might save you some time, don't turn on the headset right away, plug it into its charger, and short press the power button, that won't turn the headset on, only turn on the display briefly to show the power level, it turns on the screen and is mostly black, so if you have a stuck pixel, usually green, red or blue, can be white some times, they are pretty small, so it might take you a few minutes, honestly give yourself 3 minutes at least to find it if its there, but its more visible while the screen is on a dark image, i.e the charging screen, if your lucky, and did not spot a stuck pixel,then go ahead and unplug the headset, power the headset on, during the start screen look around for a black dot that will not go away, a black pixel, sadly is a dead pixel, this happen on my third attempt, why sadly, well with a stuck pixel you at least have a chance to fix it, all though the chances are very low, and I've yet to find anyone that has been able to fix a stuck pixel on the Oculus Quest 2, which usually requires hours of flashing the spot of your screen with the dead pixel with a video flashing between red, green blue for at least 1 but up to 4 hours, some times longer,and if your extremely lucky, and got one with out a stuck or dead pixel, wow . . . . . If you were not lucky, like me, well at least you know a little faster way to spot a dead or stuck pixel, I'd wish you luck but, as I pointed out above, I have non to spare all though I wish it for anyone who dares to attempt to get a perfect quest 2.Otherwise, if you can do without VR right now, do so, or if you can afford a Valve Index, then get a Valve Index, if you don't have a computer to power the Valve Index and or if you can't afford a Index, just be prepared to accept a product that's likely to have a permanent dot, in which case all though my experience so far is very limited, it might not be so hard to live with, though I have not had enough time with my dot, to know if its truly possible to live with, though you'll find ALOT more glowing reviews for the Quest 2 so maybe it really is possible, I'm honestly surprised there are not pages of people mentioning dead or stuck pixels, though there are plenty outside of amazon.

I purchased this for my son for Christmas. He was overjoyed and excited. As he started to try to install it to his  nitro gaming laptop he found that this particular device did not have the graphics card needed to be present to support this device. He was on customer support for over an hour they tried several things we wound up having to return it. My son is heartbroken and I am very angry. If you go on the site there is literally a listing of 6 to 10 laptops and computers that are not compatible with this gaming device. Knowing this The designers have yet to fix this problem since it’s release in 2018 and update their product! I think that they should make it apparent to the consumer that there are certain needs to support this accessory before they purchase it and break their kids heart on Christmas!
review_title: Is NOT supported by ALL computers

one_reviews_text: Let me preface this by saying, I've never been a video game player, just not my thing. I got this for Christmas, and all I can say is...Wow. As a former ping-pong player in my youth, I decided to give the game a shot. It is so immersive, standing in the middle of the room with the table in front of you, it feels so real. It is so realistic that I keep finding myself wanting to lean on the table for certain shots, big mistake; you need to remind yourself that the environment isn't real. Moved on to golf. Once again, you are standing in the middle of the golf course with 360-degree views of the entire scene, it's incredible.  I've only had this a few days, but if what I've seen so far is any indication, I am a video game person. I just had to find the correct format. Love it.

I love this, though I wish it were a bit wider for use with glasses, and I wish they sold replacement cushions for it more inexpensively as I am sweating. Otherwise, it's nearly perfect! This is a very polished experience.Wireless is super important. While I did get the pricey link cable for use with my PC, and I will be playing PC games on this headset, I underestimated how much better it is to be wireless. I will explore the Airline (wireless PC connection) too, but again using this with a PC adds a layer of complexity. If you want to use this by itself for a quick session, that's where it really shines as it's easy to put on and go.While Oculus is owned by Facebook, and they're begging for government regulation, AND the default sharing settings are too leaky for my taste, I am willing to compromise. I see this as my first, but not last, VR system. I will upgrade in a few years as technology improves, and will consider a different company's platform then. But for now this is a great way to try out VR.The apps are well done and include usual video apps from youtube, amazon prime, and netflix. I am using a few inexpensive games, mostly for fitness and that's working well. You can use transparency mode to set up a virtual safe zone so you can move freely and it'll let you know if you are going out of it. Just very impressive how well it all works.With regard to glasses, I use an older pair that are narrow and fit better. I don't use the included silicone face pad cover because that does get caught on the smaller glasses and that's not good. So, if it's sweaty I detach the face pad and clean it...but I foresee that it won't last forever. Replacements seem to be pricy but I will also experiment with aftermarket ones. A side benefit to this being such a big selling product is that there are numerous third party accessories for it.
review_title: Excellent intro to VR at a great price and wireless

one_reviews_text: Great headset, the kids' love it but nowhere in the product description does it mention it requires a Facebook account so Mark Zuckerberg can data mine your personal information.

I was an early adopter of PSVR.  Over the years I played it less and less, just because it was a hassle to set up.  Not that it was hard, just that it was annoying.The fact that Quest 2 is standalone and no wires is EXACTLY why it's so amazing.  I've had it for nearly 2 months now and I play it every day.  Sometimes multiple times a day.I use it for workouts, which I didn't know was even a thing.  If I can be tricked into physical activity, great!I also having been using Virtual Desktop to tap into my PC so I can run Steam VR.  It works perfectly, all wireless.  128GB is plenty of space if you are debating.Here's an example of a major improvement.  My daughter would use PSVR and I would need to be near to make sure she wouldn't hit the TV or something and have to help her not get tangled up with the cord.  Now with Oculus I set up a Guardian so she can clearly see the invisible walls I set for her and no longer need to untangle her from cords.  You can also stream to a TV using Chromecast or the phone app so you can see what the user is seeing.  The app also gives you control to help them launch games or reset their position.  These improvements are HUGE!I've been BLOWN AWAY how much better the Quest 2 is over older VR headsets, especially PSVR.  Everything looks better and plays with better controls.  I can't see this going down the same road with PSVR where I stop using it, it's just really really good.
review_title: This is the VR headset EVERYONE needs

one_reviews_text: The biggest drawback with this headset is the weak USB port and other charging issues. It doesn't take much pressure to break that USB port and once you break it, u might as well throw the whole headset away because there is absolutely no way to repair or replace it. Check the internet for all of the complaints concerning the headset's charging issues and you'll see what I mean. My headset lasted for about 2 months and with the continuous charging, eventually the port became weak and broke and the cable started melting the headset housing around the USB port to the point that it completely stopped charging. Never again will I buy another Oculus headset. A waste of $300.
review_title: Don't waste your money...wait for something more reliable.

one_reviews_text: Likes:-Games are good! Plenty to choose from.-Audio is ok. You can enable Bluetooth earbuds/headphones-VR is in par with Playstation VR but better since you can create a safe space (guardian) and walk around in VR vice just sitting or standing with PSVR.-Quality is good. Combination of plastic and elastics. Not heavy and can play for 3hrs with minimum neck fatigue.-Sickness? Not that bad depending on game/video. For the most part I only felt sick when playing seated. Watching videos didn’t make me sick at all. Now for the bad.-Facebook: Not so much of a bad but more of a why. Seems a bit sketchy having a system with cameras all around watching your home as you traverse on a VR environment. Guardian safe zone? More like now I know your living space and where you spend most the time. Also thanks for the cool interior pics of your house.- Price: I can see myself playing this for a little bit, not as often as my home console. Not that I will stop playing it, but more like not worth $299.99 playing every day type. FYI I got the $200 discount from the Amazon credit card so I only payed $109.00ish.-Head Strap: By far the worst thing this VR headset has. Not only is it uncomfortable but seems like it will break anytime in the near future. Everything points to OCULUS wants you to buy their premium strap.-Battery life: Depending on use you can squeeze like 2.5-3 tops on hours of playtime. This is if you are moderate with what you got turned on and turn it fully off when not in use.I will keep updating this review as time goes by as we all know this was a hot XMas present in 2021. Pandemic and all everyone is down to do some indoor travel a la VR Mode.
review_title: You’re missing out. 3hrs of Fun Per Charge.

one_reviews_text:
无法加载媒体。
                



 It was the hit of Christmas. My boys (husband and son) have played it everyday since! They love connecting with friends, meeting new people via games, and the fully immersing experience. I love the work out! This VR system was a win-win for the whole house.

This was purchased as a Christmas gift for my 12yo daughter. It is a huge hit, not only for her, but her Dad and I have had a blast on it also! Once you have the headset on it feels like you are really in the VR game you are playing. As a parent I like you set perimeters of the room you are playing in and once you leave the set perimeters the game pauses and you can see where you are in the room. This is a great safety feature, especially if you are playing in a room with a lot of obstacles or stairs. Set up was easy, we did have to set up a Facebook account, which I wasn't thrilled about. But, once it is set up it is managed from the VR headset or the app. She has had a blast playing gorilla tag with a couple of her school friends that got the Oculus as well.

Maybe it's because I live in a studio apartment with my elderly, dementia parent. Maybe it's because I'm not interested in getting outside as much due to covid. Or maybe it's inflation. Whatever the reason or excuse, I LOVE the escape these glasses give me.It's addictive!To feel snuggly, alone, and transported is SOO AWESOME!I not only visit other countries, but I love going under water, or overhead with a drone sky-view of the world.I love the feel of the rollercoaster rides. So funny how our minds can cause physical reactions. Love it! Don't get that belly-drop feel, any more - belly's too fat - but I do get a wonderful dizzy feel when descending down the rollercoaster.Watching TV or Prime/Netflix is synonymous to being in my own media room, curled up and cozy.I haven't played any games yet.As interested as I am in AI, the introduction robot creeped me the heck out because it looked me in my eyes and danced with me, responded to my dance movements. How is that possible? Or is that a real human, drawn to look like a colorful stick figure? Rushed through that and never returned.Very meditative. You will fall asleep with this on, several times.I wait till my parent is sleep then I indulge, but since she likes to compete with me - once again proving how young she really is (sigh), I only use once every two weeks. At the end of the day, too tired to put on knowing I'd be snoring within seconds.You can use with Bluetooth or plugin headset, too.I've decided to gift one to someone everyone every year.Enjoy!
review_title: I'm Afraid To Post A Review. Why? Because I Enjoy It Too Much!

one_reviews_text: This unit seems to be very glitchy. I tried hooking it up to my PC and tried it solo. Games that require "hand motion" detect ghost controllers no matter how far away I put the real ones(even put them outside in the car trunk.) When I am hooked to my Gaming PC via airlink, it starts off great but then gets really glitchy within minutes.  The virtual desktop and VR navigation seems to disappear and reappear out of reach...at will. Also, the Oculus Store is inaccessible then it's accessible...then inaccessible again only to be accessible for another brief window only to be inaccessible yet again...you get the idea.My PC is running at around 12% maximum disk use and 110-120 processes. I am running a 10th gen i9 with a dedicated video card and 32gb of RAM...so, if it's not going to work airlinked because my hardware isn't up to snuff then it should not be listed that it's wirelessly PC compatible at all.I ordered a 10ft ultra high speed USB C to USB C data cable to see if it works better when physically tethered. The unit comes with what seems like an intentionally short USB C charging cable in an attempt to sell their way overpriced 10 ft cable. So...we'll see in a few days when the cable arrives.On a side note, why in the world would the manufacturer's design include a power button right underneath the strap? Every time a player tries to physically adjust the headset they unintentionally close everything out only to reopen and find everything aggravatingly rearranged.I thoroughly expected to see my daughter using the headset and sailing through virtual worlds on Christmas morning and not getting so frustrated that she gave up even trying to use it.Maybe my unit is defective. If it's the same way after the new cable arrives then I intend to ask for either a refund or a working replacement.EDIT: The main reason we bought this VR setup was for Roblox VR. The high speed cable came in and VOILA! the glitchy PC connection is no more. The only issue now seems to be that we have to uninstall the headset, restart the PC and reinstall the Quest 2 headset every time we want to use it tethered. However, my daughter loves the Roblox VR play and says it rocks...so, looks like we're going to keep the unit.

I'm a computer-literate senior. I find this fascinating: it literally opens new vistas.  I've pretty much left action games alone, since the old text-based Zork multi-user-dungeon.  Oculus allows me to interact (or not) with fellow Avatars watching various activities, like musical, sports, religious, natural drone vistas, etc. My favorite App (so far) is VR on the International Space Station. 360 degree view of members aboard the craft, explaining various functions; showing you how they exercise, eat, etc. Fascinating! The view from their viewing platform on the ISS is spectacular.Like learning any new tool whether digital or mechanical; expect a learning curve. Do the tutorials, like how to use the controls.  When it gets too frustrating, take a break. Remember, this is supposed to be fun. Repetition facilitates learning.
review_title: Even Old Dogs Can Learn New Tricks

one_reviews_text: I saw when these types of headsets came out and I thought the companies would make some improvements as time went on.  These are so HEAVY on my face and very uncomfortable.  In addition in the nose section (after adjusting straps a million times) I could see my REAL rug while trying to pay attention.  I also feel with the expense of the item, some really good FREE apps would have been great to really let me get the hang of it.  Most for adults have FREE with in app purchases.  I am sending them back.

What they don't tell you about the Quest 2 is that its more narrower than the previous headsets meaning that you have to force your glasses into it which doesn't provide for a very pleasant experience as the glasses dig into the side of your head, you could buy $200 VR lenses (if you have bad vision like me) which at that point I would rather like to track down a Rift S instead.Avoid if you have glasses unless you can justify buying the lenses as well, ontop of a headstrap that should have been included and a 3rd party oculus link cable.

 We bought this for my grandsons birthday and he loved it as you can see in the video..

This was a big purchase for us and wow, was it worth it.  We use it primarily for the Supernatural exercise program (requires a subscription).  If you want an incredibly fun -- positively addictive, really -- way of getting your cardio and building some muscle, this is for you.  Being new to VR, I was concerned that the Oculus setup would be difficult and that there would be a steep learning curve.  Nope.  The Oculus takes you through everything you need to do seamlessly.  We have upgraded the head strap and added grip covers (both from Kiwi) as they help keep everything in place when you are moving around as much as we are in Supernatural.  For more stationary apps, the stock setup should be fine.  One thing to be aware of if you wear glasses -- smaller frames fit fine but larger frames will get squished.  Considering the cost of eyeglasses, this is a definite consideration.  We both got prescription VR Wave lenses that fit in the Oculus and this solves that problem (about $100 each and they work amazingly well, even with strong prescriptions.)  So if you are going to just be playing fairly stationary games and don't need glasses, this $300 expenditure will probably be it.  If you want to do what we do, or wear glasses, expect to be spending a bit/lot more.  Would we buy it again?  Absolutely.

My 8-year-old woke up today with a severe rash on his face. After mom freaked out we realized it was exactly were the foam from the headset sits..A quick Google search revealed FB the Criminals know about this.NO RECALL!NO WARNING ON THE PACKAGE!Their solution. wait for your kid to have a severe reaction and if your lucky enough to figure out where it came from you can spend 20 minutes trying to find support. Then you have to wait in chat for 344 other unhappy customers.Then they will send you a silicone cover for the problem they are aware of and don't care to fix and or warn you about.

(Updated) My son spent his own birthday and holiday presents for over a year to buy this and he loved it.  He loved it so much that all he wanted for Christmas was games for it.  Then it stopped logging in and became unusable.  5 days later trying to resolve with customer support and I've had it.  There's no one to talk to, just chat or email, and all their fixes have failed, even a factory reset.  The weak link here is that it relies on Facebook for everything so if their interface with Facebook breaks down, you lose all access.My 9 year old son is devastated.  I'm furious and out many hours because of their terrible customer service.  Regretting this purchase.If they miraculously come through, I will update but for now... 1 star.Updated: Amazon comes through for the win!  After Oculus's disastrous excuse for customer service, I contacted Amazon and a real human arranged for a replacement THE NEXT DAY!!!  And it works!  My son is happy, I'm happy, I just hope if it breaks down again Amazon can help with the problem because Oculus won't.So yes, super fun, but be aware that if there's a problem, Oculus is not helpful in fixing it.
review_title: Stopped working after 3 months, customer service is a joke

one_reviews_text: Doubt anyone will read this review but I have to say I am really into VR. If you have a gaming pc, just download desktop VR and play from your pc, you do have to have a fast router though. I tried the cable but it sucks to have a cable dangling so go wireless, you probably will lose some quality but its wireless so. Oh and Oculus does have its own wireless option to stream from PC but so far I have had less issues with destop VR, I ran into issues using oculus air-link. IDK I could be wrong anyways get this thing its dope, you don't have to just stick to the games from Oculus store, I am playing my steam games, hooked on Skyrim rn, glad i never beat it cause now it really feels like I am in the game.
review_title: I am loving this VR stuff.

I go other new VR more a expensive than I leave FB bye go to FB. Peoples and me never buy FB/META VR bankruptcy down.

I like the fact that you don't have to use your phone with all the Oculus apps. Once you download the Quest app it is on the headset and all you have to do is use the headset to play games.  There is not anything that I don't like about the Quest 2 so far.  I am very impressed with the new games for the Quest 2.  There are a lot of free games to keep anyone happy.  Of course some of the best games that they have are ones that you have to pay for.  I have gotten at least 6 paid games so far.  Prices vary between 3.99 to 39.99,  which was very good for my budget right now.
review_title: You should charge  the headset until the light turns green which means it's completely charged.

one_reviews_text: Very impressed by the meta quest 2 graphics, sound, ease of use navigating is really pretty much straight forward just follow prompts and you're good to go. For a VR headset you really do get a lot of value for your money. Not to mention it's a stand alone headset, meaning no need to have your headset wired to a PC (unless you still wanna do it that way, cause you can using a link cable) but why would you want to do that? Personally I use AirLink and it works GREAT! Bringing my family of gamers together and moving is just one of the many benefits this has provided for us and with all the news surrounding the meta verse, it seems we are just starting and will only get better moving forward. 1 potentially HUGE downside for some... As of writing this review you NEED a Facebook account in order to set up your quest 2 VR headset. Fingers crossed this will be removed as a requirement in the near future. But it is still a lot of fun.

I got this for my 9 yr old son for his Christmas gift. And while I know Oculus is affiliated with Meta/Facebook, I don’t like the fact that in order to use the toy - you HAVE to have an active Facebook account. Not a throw away account like I wanted to set up.While my son loves the oculus, I find the cost of the games you can buy to be super expensive. So it makes the ability to get him a variety of games difficult. $30 on average is a tough pill to swallow after paying $300 for the device.But my biggest gripe is having to have a Facebook account to have access to the device. I believe they’re going to change it. I still hate it cause I hate Facebook.You should have an option to set up access without having Facebook. Period.Take that away? The Oculus is a good purchase since my son loves it.

 Compared to my original quest, this one is much faster, lighter, and has more memory space. I would recommend getting this or upgrading to it. I would also recommend being careful with it as the strips are white fabric and can be stained easily.

I was skeptical, but my son wanted one. It is way better than you might think. I ended up getting one for myself. I can play games like mini golf with my son when he is at his mothers house. I use it mainly for exercise (supernatural) on which I am totally hooked. Best exercise innovation in a decade without a doubt. It is just so fun you don’t feel hardly any effort of getting your heart rate up to a level for aerobic fitness. In fact my main issue has been over exercising with it, even though I am pretty fit. I also use it for meditation. There are a number of apps for that. None are perfect but right now Tripp is the best. While the meditation apps don’t yet live up to the incredible production value of supernatural, nonetheless I am very impressed at how the immersive nature of VR helps shift me into a more meditative state much more rapidly and with much less effort than standard meditation - which I am quite experienced at.
