What you will need to run the games is far beyond the scope of this review, and you may want to consult someone who knows about computers to ask if your setup is powerful enough to run VR. Also, the Link cable needs to be secure, one tip I have is to use a strap, usually included with VR cables, and strap it to the side of the headset neat where the charge port is. This will keep the cord from dangling straight down and occasionally disconnecting the link. Also with the stock strap, run the cable through the middle of the headstrap, then to the charge port then use the individual strap, so the cable runs down your back, not your side, helps to keep you from being twisted up. One other downside is the Link does still use battery life with many setups due to the power being sent to your headset being lower than the usage, still can get many hours of play at full charge, and able to go again the next day for just as long. I don't know much about using Air Link or Virtual Desktop for wireless Link connections so, I can't comment. I tried, it didn't work very smoothly for me.Final conclusion or a TLDR: This headset is likely one of the best headsets for entering VR, for any reason. Watching movies on a big giant virtual screen can never get old to me, or meeting friends "face to face" on a game using the Link function, or hitting blocks that fly past me to a song's rhythm in beat saber to exercise a little in doors, whatever I use it for, it works, and well. It isn't the best VR headset out there, but it is the current best Standalone VR headset to date. Capacity wise, 128 GB is fine, but with too many games, you may run into storage problems, but seeing how everything on the Headset is digital, things are easily deleted and re-installed as needed. Resolution is nice, comfort is acceptable with some issues but minor, and the quality of the build is good. At no point have I ever thought I wasted my money on this, if anything, I wish I had gotten it sooner. Oh one other feature I want to mention is that due to it using cameras to see the outside world for tracking purposes, you can also look outside of VR without ever taking off the headset. Through passthrough, you can see the outside world in Black and White. Very handy feature that I believe all headsets after this one need to include. For the price, this is an easy sell, highly recommend buying this headset, and going from there. If you're looking for the best of the best VR PC headset, this isn't that, but it is a great entry level PC headset, that won't steer you wrong. Mine hasn't let me down, and shows no signs that it will.
review_title: A great headset, made better by increased capacity for no additional cost over the old 64GB model.

one_reviews_text: I'm new to VR, aside from playing with some Google Cardboard-like devices.  The instant you put this on, it's astounding!  It's like stepping through the looking-glass, Alice.  They're smart enough to have to sit down to go through the setup routine, but there's really no dizziness.This is presented by Facebook, so you do have to have a Facebook account.  If you don't have one, signing up is easy, and no one will be getting into your private life.I found that I had a little trouble keeping focus; you have to keep it strapped tightly to your face to maintain optimum distance.  Also, there's a little bit of a light gap around my nose, but that's quickly forgotten.  There are a number of free games and applications to get you started.  I sprang for the 256Gb version (More is Better!) so as not to run out of storage in the future.  Some of the controls are a little confusing at first, but again, you get used to it.  The tutorial is good at teaching you how to do things.  It's a lot of fun, in fact!  Luckily, it runs on rechargeable batteries that eventually wear down, or else I might keep this strapped on all day long!
review_title: Mind-boggling experience!  Transported to different worlds!

one_reviews_text: My husband got this for our family as covid continued to stump our less than motivated selves from gym time.  We opted for this rather than buying another piece of exercise equipment as it seemed like the most adjustable way for both of us to get a little cardio in and make the kids move.I've now had the headset for 4 months, and I still love it.  It is still working well.  My kids still play with it, but not as fervently as when we first got it (think family schedule, begging, trading, and bargaining for extra time).  Now I get it out on days I don't have other exercise planned, my husband gets it out 2 days a week when the weather is crumby and my kiddos get it out 1-2 times a week to play their favorite games.I still love it.Friends - Everyone who comes over wants to use this.  The kids have us hide it when friends come over as they don't want the friend to stay on the headset the whole time.  It is simple to set a new boundary up and prompts you when you are in a new area to do so.  They even have stationary area sets so you wont injure yourself (or your stuff) in a small area.  We take it when we travel and have friends and family play with it, for all of our amusement.  Also because quite a few folks bought earlier tech and had bad experiences, that just don't know that it can be quite this good!  When the dog or cat enters the zone the headset warns us to check to make sure the playarea is still "safe."  We can choose to ignore it right then (like during tai chi) or act and put the dog outside or get it a bone to chew so it doesn't get karate kicked in the face during more energetic games.Motion sickness.  I have severe issues with motion sickness and am VERY glad that the shaky cam movies that made me have to sleep off a motion sickness bout are out of style.  I can't sit as a passenger in a car, even the front.  I can't ride roller coasters or ride an amusement park ride more than once before I look like I've been binge drinking.  I can't play Portal and many Spiderman games as my brain just can't handle it.  It's embarrassing and affects me daily.  I was MOST worried about his when we got the headset.  I was surprised that when I adjusted the headset to adapt to my pupillary distance (hold the sides of the lenses and push appart) and made sure it was lined up (move the headset up and down till it looks like you are just looking through glasses then twist back strap to hold in place)... it was ok.  I do this adjustment every time and it takes under a few seconds now.  No matter who is wearing it (kiddo or man with  giant head).  I started easy with a few games that just wanted me to look around.  I moved up to beat saber and even got into supernatural.  There was one game that was a complete spiderman experience that had me hugging the floor and down for the count, but one out of the 30 games we tried.  I have a list of fitness options that don't make me ill, and get me cardio, and are fun enough that I have to "take turns" with my kids.  They get a little fitness and don't even notice.  I get a full sweat work out.  I have dance cardio, I have boxing, I have tai chi etc., any time, no excuses.  We even bought an extended battery pack to make sure.. no excuses.  My husband sprung for the attached heart monitor.Talking about size of the headset, I have to buy my husband hats at the bighead store.  Literally a store for folks who have heads so large they can't get baseball caps, construction hats, visors, sunglasses and other hats to fit their gigantic heads.  I myself am very tall and have to usually wear men's hats, and had no problems fitting this on my head (or more importantly my husband's huge gourd of a head).  I find with my larger forehead that I have to make sure my pony tale is not under a strap to place it correctly so I don't get any blur.As for pupillary distance, I was curious when I read the reviews about this, because man.. it is able to move quite a bit to accommodate what folks need.  I noted that pupillary distance (wikipedia posted the army study of 6000 people, mind you) noted that distance beyond 72 was more than 99th percentile.  So it is possible, to check if you have a distance more than 74mm between your pupils you can use a rule in a mirror, though honestly not sure on the sets max pupillary distance and just noting the popular review on here noted he had unusually far distance from one to the other so trying to help folks check their size (though 99% of the time should be fine).  So it is very uncommon for people to have eyes and pupils that far apart that would need the headset to move even further out, but we are human.  But it is easy to measure, take a ruler and a mirror and see how far apart in mm your pupils are.  There are walk throughs online for folks who order glasses.  If you need to make absolutely sure, but again 99% of the time it's not needed.Kids - some games are super easy for them to pick up.  Especially the games that have no set endpoint (like the work games where you can replace an engine with a potato to try and get it to run better).  Some games are a lot like the ones they play in roblox (like hole in the wall, where you have to move to be a certain shape).  Though some games you need to go into options and set to the height of whomever is wearing it.  We now have 3 games which are their favorites to go back to and 2 or 3 that they played through and are done.  The first week we had to have a schedule to play, but it has relaxed to getting it out for family time.  This is best done buy having a phone linked to the headset that allows OTHERS TO SEE WHAT YOU ARE SEEING.  We put it up on an IPAD and get to laugh along with the person playing.  It also helps for "turns" when someone doesn't want to give up the headset.  There are even games that allow other's to join in the silly by playing WITH the person with the headset on, they play their ipads WITH the headset person.  It is all quite silly.Facebook - I don't recall linking it to anything at this point, but we've had it for months.  If you hate that idea, use a fake profile.
review_title: Plus size work outs AND babysitting

one_reviews_text: I ordered 2 headsets for family fun.  Setting up an Oculus App account on my phone while waiting for delivery.  This also requires Facebook registration. Facebook just disabled my account, immediately.  They want my telephone and photograph?  Really?  Sorry, I just ordered two headsets and to be treated this way is ridiculous.  Steam, Origin, Microsoft, Sony, and other gaming systems/services don't ban anyone or require as much to join.  If you remove Facebook requirements from the Oculus, I may reconsider, but I will  never forget this treatment.  I had no idea how awful Facebook really was until my first contact with them.

You need a Facebook account to even start this device and when you read the user agreement you’ll realize that Facebook collects so much data about you from this device it’s ridiculous! And Facebook can block your account any time for any reason which causes the oculus 2 to be a brick.
review_title: You need to create a Facebook account

one_reviews_text: Enough has been said about the Oculus/Facebook stuff, but it is truly atrocious. I've been using my Rift for years, long before the account merger debacle. I bought the Quest 2 because the hardware looked great, even though I was worried that a problem merging my Oculus account to Facebook might bite me if I ran into problems with it. Long story short: it did, and I've spent an insane amount of time dealing with useless tech support, just to let me log into an account that I've already been using for years, on the same PC, with the same hardware (my Rift) that's sitting right next to me, all of which was utterly bricked because of their poorly implemented merger.I think the Quest 2 is a great piece of hardware. But the decisions the company has made, which can potentially make your devices unusable, is infuriating. My next headset will be from absolutely anybody else.
review_title: A good headset put out by an abysmal company

one_reviews_text:
无法加载媒体。
                



 Cons1) be prepared to spend ALOT. I spent about $600 and I still need to eat the order to play steam vr.2) battery is necessary! 2 hour life if you don't have the battery packs.3) you have to have Facebook (if you are too tight to give out your information don't get this, they are pretty invasive)Pros1) you can cast it to your smart TV and there are active games for the entire family. I have never spent this much time in the living room with all 6 of them!2) I've been spoiled by ps5 and 4k, do not expect this level of graphics. However, the graphics are very good, I've found myself flinching in game.3) I have not run into anything yet, guardian pro program is great. When you step out of it you see the whole room in greyscale.  Please ensure everyone knows you are playing boxing!I knocked my daughter out!4) "wander" is essentially Google earth in 3d, this is AWSOME!!!5) Beat Saber, if you grew up with guitar hero like me GET THIS!!!!6) thrill of the fight, if you need cardio GET THIS!Had it 2 days and my arms hurt, haven't used my heavy bag (I need to switch out, no real resistance on the game and my knuckles will get weenie!)7) my last shout out my wife plays angry birds on her phone like constantly. GET IT ON OCULUS!She's not the video game player but she was on it for hours!Overall, for our actual family entertainment, thus purchase was extremely worth the 700 I will put into it overall. I'm a horizon and elden ring ps5 guy (pre-orders already paid for) but this thing ROCKS!!!!!!With the added benefit of keeping my ps5 clear when those two games come out over the next 2 weeks!!!!
review_title: This is modern day family time necessity!

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Quest 2 itself is a fantastic device. I was even using it almost every day to work out with Supernatural. Loved that it is wireless and there's tons of content for the device.The unfortunate problem is that one's Facebook account is used to log into the device and the app.Facebook suddenly decided to suspend my account, and will only "consider" reactivating it if one uploads a driver's license or passport.If I don't provide highly personal information to Facebook, I will no longer be able to use the Oculus or all the money I've spent on games for it.I was aware of this risk, but decided to buy the device anyway, because my Facebook account only has posts of my garden and food. I did not think it would ever be suspended, but there you go.
review_title: Device works great, until Facebook disables your account

one_reviews_text: I had this for two months. I was really enjoying it. I bought some apps. It became a near daily recreation retreat for me, until... one day it wouldn't open any of my apps because it said it couldn't confirm my "entitlement" -- basically, that I had purchased the app. I went to the Oculus app on my phone to check my account, and oddly, it had logged me out. It asked me if I wanted to log in via Facebook... sure, that's what they made me do when I created my Oculus account. It said I didn't have an Oculus account, and asked me if I wanted to create one. I said yes. Big mistake. Now I've lost all my purchases. Oculus support knows this is an issue with "some users," and they say they're working on a fix, but they don't have one. It's been two weeks. I'm not hopeful at this point.When I buy something, I expect it to work. If a platform like Oculus wants to check my purchase licenses every time I open an app, it better work reliably! It's a good thing these folks don't make phones or automobiles. At first I was understanding. Now I'm upset.[UPDATE: The outage I'm describing occurred on March 8, 2022 and was resolved on March 22, 2022. I'm keeping my review low because (1) this never should have happened, and (2) the company didn't issue any official communication on the matter until March 22, after the issue was resolved. Beyond that, this is a pretty incredible platform. The biggest potential improvements I could see would be to use a screen technology like OLED where blacks are truly black and add peripheral vision (though I'm not sure that's possible). Also, I don't think it's cool how they're rebranding from Oculus to Meta. It's kind of stupid because Oculus as a brand has a favorable reputation, and all the existing games and apps are branded as Oculus.]
review_title: It's great until they lose your account with all your purchases

one_reviews_text: This is awesome. Take your gaming up a level with this! I promise, you've never used anything like it and you aren't even going to want to go back to traditional gaming systems. It's perfect for adults and kids. My 9 year old and 5 year old have no problems using it.There's a ton of games to buy and you can even watch movies!This comes already charged but you'll want to charge it as you set it up and it updates. Then, you log into your internet and Facebook and you're ready to go.The only downside is that you have to connect it to a Facebook account. I don't really like that aspect but because this is so much fun and so easy to use, I won't take off any stars.They are always uploading more games and the app is easy to use and navigate.You can also get a Chromecast so that everyone can watch what you're doing on the TV, which definitely ups the experience.

The Oculus Quest 2 is undoubtedly the best entry into VR for the price of $299. You get a sharp display and powerful enough hardware to be truly immersed. The headset doesn't require a PC so you can take it anywhere with you. It's like carrying a 80in TV with you wherever you go. There is a ton of content to keep you entertained for days. My main uses are watching my shows on the Oculus while my wife is watching her shows on the TV and gaming through Steam VR. There is a new silicone wrap for the headset included in the box to address the issues that people were having with the foam around the headset.TECH- The basic set comes with the Quest 2 headset and 2 hand controllers- The screen is sharp with 1832 x 1920 resolution per eye. You can still see the "screen door" effect but it is minimal.- 72 Hz default refresh rate but can be set all the way up to 120Hz. The downside is higher power usage and faster battery drain.- USB-C port on side to connect to PC through Oculus Link to access SteamVR- AirLink feature works well if you have a WIFI6 5GHz with a solid connectionERGONOMICS- The headset itself is front-heavy. You can adjust the horizontal strap to get a tighter fit and the vertical strap to align the headset to your eyes. I didn't get tired of wearing the headset but it does fog up on occasion when you engage in strenuous activity.- The controllers are lightweight and comfortable. The buttons are ergonomically positioned and very responsive. The tracking was near instantaneous, never once did I feel a lag.APP STORE- Many VR apps and games, but you will need to hook up Oculus Link to gain access to what I consider the premier titles on SteamVR.- Netflix, Amazon, Youtube, Showtime, ESPN, MLB are represented here. The majority of these apps are just "theater" apps, where you are sitting on a couch and there is a screen in front of you where you can sometimes change the size. More content providers need to get their wares on this store, there should be no excuses.PROS- Price is $299 for 128GB and entry into the world of VR. Nothing else comes close to the Quest 2 specs and price.- Very portable entertainment center to take anywhere with you. Effectively replaces a game console, a large screen television and your streaming device.- You can use your hands in place of controllers, the gestures are intuitive but the hand tracking needs a little more work to be more accurate.CONS- Facebook requirement is a deal-breaking decision for some. Having an Oculus account serves the same social networking purpose to link users but Facebook wants to tap into your entire social network. Luckily you can set your privacy settings now, but for how long is anyone's guess.- Missing many apps in its ecosystem to make this a no-brainer purchase.- Requires Oculus Link and high end PC to tap into the best titles in VR gaming- Eyeglass wearers might find the headset to be restricting
review_title: Unquestionably the best VR headset for the money

one_reviews_text: I’ll stay with my oculus 1 until that changes. Zuckerboy said a lot of people are resistant to this so ‘maybe’ they ‘might’ change it later to just having to have an Occulus account, like with the first ones.The box says ’from Facebook’ but occulus will not pair it without a fb account.
review_title: FORCES you to have a FACEBOOK account

one_reviews_text: I've had the Oculus Quest 2 for a couple months now, and I really like what I've seen. It offers a highly immersive and fun little escape. I'm not much of a gamer anymore, so I haven't played any of the hardcore games that the Oculus Quest 2 offers. But what I have done, is play A LOT of the PokerStars VR game! That game is free and a lot of fun.Some drawbacks that I've ran into with this system is that it's directly linked to your facebook account. Without an account, you can't do anything. Also, when facebook's servers went down a few weeks ago, the Oculus Quest 2 went down with it. There's the battery life too, which isn't that great. Usually after 1-2 hours of gameplay, the Oculus Quest 2 needs to be charged. Lastly, my wife can not use this system because only after a few minutes it will cause her to experience nausea, so just a heads up with that!All and all, I really like this console and even though I haven't used it to it's fullest potential, I can definitely see myself playing this thing for quite a while. I also believe that the tech will be a game changer in the future.

I love everything about this VR set except for the fact you need a facebook to use it.If you forget your fb pw?: No more vr headset.If you get banned off of facebook because of your "Far right extremism": No more vr headset.If facebook ever shuts down: No more VR headset.Facebook has down time?: No more vr headset. This has already happened once to me since ive had this.Facebook needs to learn boundries and self control. I'm not a fan. I like my privacy.Aside from the nasty facebook problem, I love this VR headset. My expectations were actually lower than what I received. I just wish they had a superhero game like hulk, spiderman, batman, or superman. Something like that. Or a gta 5 type of game. Some of the games are a lot of fun, but Id love a bigger and more diverse game library.Im actually kind of overweight and this gets me moving more and is way better than the console.One other thing that varies depending on the person is that it takes a while to get used to the vr experience. Some people can feel a bit woozy or have a headache after using VR. My wife gets it bad while I get it very lightly and my eldest son doesn't seem affected at all.

I recently cancelled my Facebook account due to the well publicized issues with Facebook and privacy issues. When I did it they cut off my Oculus.! How can they even legally do that.? I found the headset way too small for those with glasses even with the extension. Constantly blurry, and reception issues. Just try to get in touch with them to express your complaints. Impossible.! The Oculus is the definition of "Buyer Beware".!!

I enjoyed the selection of games and exercises and I played them often, till my headset kept shutting off and eventually never turned back on. Okay, fine. I’ll get a replacement, I thought. Once I got in touch with a CSR they said try some troubleshooting tips. I did. Then they said  they’d get back to me within a few days. Huh? So a few days later I reached out again and repeated I needed a new headset. They finally gave me an address but said they needed days to receive the product. But my tracking number showed they received it days ago. Anyway, it’s been nearly two weeks and I still don’t have a shipment date on my new headset and they have not provided an update on anything. Great selection of games  and exercises. Terrible communication and customer service.
review_title: The game selections are great, but…

one_reviews_text: I bought the Oculus Quest 2 only after watching the meta.com web presentation by FaceBook seeing all the things I could do with the unit. My main goal in buying the VR unit was to play Beat Saber to work out and have fun while doing it. Of course, Beat Saber is not the only game for the OQ 2. I found many more I would like to play and did buy another, Rez Infinite (a very good game by the way).Before I could play I had to set up the device and I will admit this took about three hours because I was stupid and could not find the power button on the sid the right side of the unit. I kept punching the volume buttons. Please do not take this to mean this is a bad unit due to this it is not at all. Now the one thing you will need in terms of software is a FaceBook.com account and you can only get the OQ 2 to work with the web membership. If you hate FaceBook do not waste your time trying to get around this issue you cannot. There are other VR system units. Also, there is an Oculus account you will need to set up after hooking into your WiFi and you will have to link this account with your FaceBook account and there is no going back. This action is permanent and FaceBook makes sure you know this fact.You may ask why. The reason is simple you want a permanent record of the games you buy so you can have them in case something happens to your unit. Now that you know this there are a few things that are amazing about the OQ 2.One, the controllers, are very easy to use, and even with your headset on and just getting ready for some game time the OQ 2 tells you which is right or left. In time you will be able to do this by feeling alone but this is a nice feature. An important point that is very good is the controllers take AA batteries and come with them just pull the tabs when you are getting started in fact you have to do this.With every gaming unit, there are issues. One that cannot be gotten around with the OQ 2 that I personally have found is this: watching the images and games through the headset can strain your eyes after about 20-25 minutes to the point they hurt. I find I cannot play without a rest period of at least 10 minutes. Another issue is that if you need glasses there is an extender for the headset that can be put in easily but using glasses is still hard. Now the good news is there are companies that sell VR unit contacts that go over the lens fit to your prescription avoiding this issue. Now, this is not an ad for them. This is only a suggestion to deal with this problem with the OQ 2. One of a few.Wrapping up on this long review and I appreciate that you have read this far the OQ 2 is a very good unit for the price. What games and things I have seen such as roller coasters POV video on YouTube is great. Then there is the fact you get what I consider a lot of battery time, 3 for apps and 2 for games as an average. As for my personal favorite, the head straps holding the headset unit to your head are very well made and very easy to adjust to any size. And one last thing: you do not need headphones or earbuds to hear the sound. The OQ 2 has built-in speakers that do a great job and the headset vibrates along with the controllers. A very nice feature.I hope your experience with the OQ 2 will be as good as mine has been so far.
review_title: A GREAT WIRELESS VR UNIT FOR THE PRICE

one_reviews_text: There is a well known drift problem with the joysticks on the controllers, and with regular use, they WILL become very difficult to use due to this inside of the two year warranty.Getting Oculus to stand behind their warranty is one of the worst warranty experiences I've ever had.  Be sure to keep your original box - there is a number on it that they need for this, and they'll also need your original receipt or invoice, be sure to keep that as well.  Learn how to take and upload video because they need that also, to see the problem.  They need all kinds of serial numbers, a drop of blood, the soul of your firstborn child, etc.It shouldn't be that hard - you guaranteed this to work for two years, it didn't.  You send me new controllers, I send you the worn out ones.  They know they will wear out inside of two years and they're banking on the hope that you haven't kept the box, receipt, or that you will get tired of answering endless emails during the replacement process.UPDATE: I am now changing my review to one star because getting them to stand behind the warranty has been one of the worst customer service nightmares I have ever been through.  The controllers stopped working over two months ago - they stalled for almost a month before telling me to send them back.  I sent them back, and they sent ONE controller to me, and it has now been ANOTHER month and they have yet to send me the other controller.  "Customer service" just sends me emails telling me that they are working on it.  I can not recommend buying anything from any company that cares so little for its customers.  I honestly feel like they don't care about their customers or their warranty after they've taken your money.Update 2:  It has now been three months since I had working controllers.  THREE MONTHS.
review_title: It's fun, but a nightmare to get them to stand behind their warranty.

one_reviews_text: This thing becomes useless if you get banned by Facebook censors. I bought an Oculus last year, then my FB account got suspended for three days, so basically it became a brick. Fortunately, this happened during the return period, so I returned it for a refund. I also permanently deleted my FB account and haven’t looked back.The arrogance of the people at FB is amazing. They think they can sell you something, require you to sign up for a FB account and then use their arbitrarily enforced community guidelines to make your Oculus useless.
review_title: Becomes a useless brick if your Facebook account gets suspended

one_reviews_text: I've had mine for over a year and the games haven't gotten any better. They only have indy games which should be fine but there are basically 4 categories, Shooter, horror, productivity and jump scare. Where are the AAA titles? Where are all the ports? Instead we keep getting what seem like demo's and just more of the same. Also, this thing is heavy on your head. It is not comfortable and the passthrough feature is like watching potato-cam footage. I would not buy this again. I didn't want to write a bad review of the Quest 2 but I lost interest way too soon and now I don't really care if the platform is abandoned, Facebook was not the best steward for this type of tech. They should have paid for more titles but they didn't or if they did, they only bought garbage, cheap android games.

I had tried a friend's Oculus Quest a couple of years ago and was really excited about the opportunity to own one myself. While we can geek out on all the capabilities, processing speed, and resolution the magical part is that quickly after putting on the headset your brain takes over and you just accept the new reality. That said, these really are a pretty amazing piece of hardware with essentially a whole computer you can wear on your head.FaceBook did a keynote not long ago where they talked about the fact that they are doubling down on virtual reality as a key part of the "metaverse". The good news is that if there was any question about if Oculus was going to have support from FaceBook their parent company they have made it clear that under the new company name "Meta", Virtual Reality is a big part of their vision. They also answered some questions about the future or the product with some ideas like at a future date you will be able to use Oculus without a Facebook account and you'll be able to separate your business virtual reality from your personal one.For playing games, the Quest is an amazingly immersive experience and I love that it is active. I regularly build up a sweat playing games on the Quest.The one experience I feel like the Quest isn't quite there yet is media consumption. It is awesome that there are apps like Hulu and Netflix on Quest and the idea of having a virtual screen the size of a movie theater is incredible. If you are in a situation where you don't have access to a TV, it would be a great way to consume media. For most people, it is likely that they are using their Quest in the same room as their television and you'll have a better picture just watching your TV than using the quest.Overall very happy with the "Oculus Quest 2 — Advanced All-In-One Virtual Reality Headset — 128 GB". It is a great experience and definitely the future of not just gaming but many asp[ects of life.

If you've never tried VR before THIS is the way to start!The Quest 2 is an amazing addition to the library of VR options available these days. First off the device itselfIts VERY lightweight! When I got the box I was curious if it actually had a VR unit in it. It did obviously! The device is very modest in size and weight. Don't let that fool you, this is a very powerful machineSetup is quite easy. Most will require an update and depending your internet this could take awhile. Also be aware there is a required facebook account (which is obviously free) which some complain about but personally I don't see why all the gripe since its a device designed by facebook.There are several options of customizations for this. From straps to face covers etc, making you're quest easily able to fit your needs.Graphics are superb, competing with high end very expensive units. The resolution and refresh rate is even better than some high end pc VR units!Best part is the quest 2 can easily run WITH your PC. An excellent feature enabling you to (with some additional software) play games that are PC based, ON your quest 2 with the higher refresh rates. THIS is awesome because with again, the right software you can play wirelessly, making VR VERY immersive!Given this DOES require a high end PC and wifi connection.Gaming library is expanding nearly everyday! Some games are just gimicky like alot of vr titles these days but several high end games are coming out. I wont mention any but they are easily researchable , and strongly suggest checking out the libraries available.Battery life is 'ok' at roughly 2 hrs of gaming, but several options available allow increasing that, from battery pack addons to corded play.Durability is okay, just obviously don't treat it rough cause it IS a high tech machine.Onboard sensors are the best part for you don't need any external sensory devices like other VR devices out there so its purely a true standalone device. Easy to just pick up and play at your convenience.Also built in with a guardian feature which allows you to set boundaries preventing you from destroying furniture and or things like your TV depending where you play LOL.The controllers are VERY comfortable! And the battery life is amazingly epic. The power stayed at 100% for days of playing before it started dropping. Compared to other devices which batteries may last a few days I could see these puppies lasting weeks if not longer. They are very sensitive controllers and the quest 2 now features 'hand recognition' so with some apps and games you don't even need controllers!If you never have tried VR I strongly suggest starting with this hardware. Its not very expensive but very high end on the spectrum, and it will be a good investment assuming you are into gaming and VR gaming.Seriously check this out if interested in VR. Whether new or looking to check out new hardware, totally worth it and one of the best priced hardware's I've seen.
review_title: Excellent entertainment value! Whole new worlds exist for the taking!

one_reviews_text: This is the new Oculus Quest 2, which is basically exactly the same as the older Quest except that it comes with half the memory, 128Gb of inbuilt storage rather than 256Gb and is priced $100 cheaper than the 256Gb version.The Quest 2 is the perfect entry level headset to find out whether or not you like the VR world.  Some people don't  like VR for various reasons including vertigo and the feeling of getting sick, neck pain as the headsets are fairly heavy on your head etc.  Other people love it and spend hours on it.For your money your will get the headset itself, a fairly comfortable elastic strap to attach it to your head, two controllers and a charging cable.  Setup is fairly simple. You connect it to your phone using bluetooth and just follow the prompts.  You will need a Facebook account to tie it to and this puts some people off (I understand why) but the majority of people already have a facebook account anyway.The Quest 2 has 2 1832x1920 LCD screens. Not quite 4K but a higher resolution than HD.  For the money this isn't bad, especially considering the higher resolution Rift S is double the price.  The eye pieces are slightly adjustable to 3 different positions, dependent upon the size of your head and space between your eyes.  One great thing about the LCD display is that you can adjust the frame rate.  I have mine set to 72Hz which I feel is much smoother than default 60Hz setting and this makes me much less prone to feeling sick.  There is also a 90Hz refresh rate however for PC gaming that is too high unless you have a seriously beefy graphics card.  Note however that you do not need a PC to use this.The headset also has 3D capable audio built directly into the headset.  The sound quality is OK but nothing outstanding. As such a lot of people also wear headphones when using the Quest 2 and there is a built in 3.5mm audio port to hook your headphones into.  Personally, the sound is good enough for me and I prefer using it without the added weight of a pair of headphones.The headset is quite heavy and although the soft elastic strap that comes with it is adequate, I would highly recommend purchasing one of the Elite, hard backed straps that you can find on amazon. These do make a lot of difference in distributing the weight, making wearing the headset much more comfortable and you can wear it for longer.The Quest 2 has hundreds of apps and games available for it, from watching netflix and shooting games to fitness and boxing games.  Even games such as boxing do help you to get in shape as you quickly find yourself ducking and weaving as well as throwing punches as you get immersed in the gameplay.  These games are stored in the 128Gb of memory in the headset and aren't that large so even with 128Gb you should have plenty of room for a number of games and apps.You can also attach your headset to your PC and play VR games on your PC.  To do this you will need to buy an Oculus cable. The official one comes in at $80 which is very pricey.  You can find third party cables that do the exact same thing for much less.  I love to play DCS and Flight Simulator 2020 on my PC with the Quest.  The immersion takes it to a whole other level, however in order to do so you will also need a fairly beefy PC to handle the graphics.  My PC is a couple of years old, so its not powerful enough to turn up all the textures in Flight Sim to Ultra, but it is good enough to play with reasonably high definition.  Honestly this is the main use I have for the Quest 2.  At somepoint I will probably upgrade to the Rift S, but a new PC is in order before that.So if your interested in dabbling with VR or don't have the budget to buy the Rift S then I would highly recommend the Quest 2.  This 128Gb version, coming in at just $300 is well worth the money and I very highly recommend it.
review_title: A superb entry to the world of VR

one_reviews_text: I have been playing with this for a little less than three weeks now (so that I could deliver the most thorough and accurate review possible). And, overall, I am really pleased. Now, this is not my first experience with the Oculus: I did have the first gen one. And, a lot has changed for the better (which is truly impressive).Foremost, this is way lighter than the first gen Oculus (which is great). And, the battery here has a longer life as well (which means more play-time without a break for a charge ... and I love that).Now, unlike the first version, the "focus range" here has preset numbers instead of the range that was available in the first gen. So, there are larger increments which may mean very slightly less overall clarity.This is truly so much more comfortable than the first gen version. The first one was very front-heavy (which we would sometimes counterbalance with a little weight on the back). Here, you don't need any mods at all: it has great balance. (And that is the absolute best!)Overall, this has great hand-tracking which allows you to operate the Oculus without any controllers at all. And, that will always amaze me!Beat Saber looks great, the game is great, and there is even a 360 mode which this Quest excels at (since there are no wires unlike the Valve Index).Likewise, there are so many free videos that you can enjoy! So, much can be watched without further investment of money (which is great for those with kids who are always seeking something new). And, many of these freebies are educational: you can learn about history, take tours of various landmarks, explore overhead views of cities, etc. You can even have a 360 experience on the moon! It's very cool!You can add Oculus friends and play games with them (which is really great for those who are maintaining their "personal bubbles" right now). Love that!In sum, it is 100% worth upgrading from the first gen version to this one. It's a fantastic starting point for VR! Very highly recommended!

As I've already been enjoying virtual reality games and apps since 2019 with my Oculus Rift S headset, picking up the Oculus Quest 2 was a no-brainer for me. Unlike the Rift S, which requires a wired connection to a beefy gaming PC, the Quest 2 has no such requirements and all I needed was my smartphone to set up the Quest 2 and quickly get started playing. Yay to no more twisted and tangled up wire that I have to unwind once in a while to remove the annoying kinks. 👍As a result of being freed from wires, I can enjoy my games in more environments and I no longer have to pack as much stuff when taking it to friends' houses; carrying a 10-lb gaming laptop and its heavy charger is no fun.Being free from a powered PC, of course, means a shorter continuous playtime since you're limited by the built-in battery size and life. There is a way, however, to extend your playtime through a device such as the 
X-super Home Adjustable Elite Strap with Battery Bracket
 - by strapping on a powerbank to the strap, game time can be extended for a couple more hours. Such a setup adds some weight but I consider it a worthy trade-off.My favorite VR game is Beat Saber and I was disappointed to find out that I had to purchase it again ($29.99). Due to the great exercise it offers, though, I purchased the game again, and playing it on the Quest 2 is just as fun and accurate as playing on the Rift S.Unlike my Rift S, the Quest 2 came with a silicone cover inside the box which was a pleasant surprise.Just like the Rift S, the speakers on the Quest 2 are so-so. I recommend watching shows & playing games with some quality headphones jacked in to up the feeling of immersiveness.At $299.00 (as of 2021-09-15), the Quest 2 is priced like a regular game console (e.g., Nintendo Switch) and I think it's fairly priced for all the high-tech VR you can experience and a library of quality and fun titles that are available. It's a 5-Star Win!
I cannot understand why people so freely provide their information to beasts like Facebook. They are trying to understand everything about you to manipulate you.

I bought my Quest2 4 days ago, and I can't get past the headset screen with the password # on it...Phone will not connect with FB on the Oculus APP. Many customers have same problem! Here are some of my solutions that Oculus does not give you!  1.Headset hand controls are supplied with AAA batteries  2.  User must have a FB account  3.  If user adds an Oculus account, it must be merged with FB acct  4. Smart phone must have certain 'level'  5.  Phone and Headset must both be using the same WifI account  6. Phone must have Bluetooth turned on  7. User must know the WIFI password  8.  Do not buy a USB-c cable unless your PC has a port. Many new Dell PCs have no USB-c port.  If your PC does not have a USB-c port, you can not connect to PC option for games (My brand new Dell laptop does not include a USB-c port.)  9. RESET YOUR HEADSET AFTER ALL OF THE ABOVE DIRECTIONS ARE COMPLETED!
review_title: Smart phone will not go to FB to pair my headset

one_reviews_text: I’ll start off by saying that this was my first VR headset, and with a price tag like that you really can’t go wrong with the quest 2. The 100% wireless feels really good, and although I had to buy a 20 dollar app at the time to playing games on my pc wirelessly as well, that also worked better than I expected. From what I can tell, my headset has been absolutely limited and plagued by the OS of the headset. After about a year with this headset, the UI bugs out like crazy on the regular, my “guardian” boundary is basically unusable at this point in lower light situations where as it was fine when I received the headset. Even with a spotlight on me, its a roll of the dice whether my headset will be able to set the guardian so I can access my headset in the first place. Even after just a few months, even in the oculus menus, the display will freeze as you’re moving which has made me sick on a couple of occasions. However, once I get past all these hurdles I cannot say it isn’t an enjoyable experience. If you don’t have a PC and want to try out VR, this is a must by. Based on my performance issues, if you have a PC and plan on utilizing it with your headset as well, it may be worth buying a different headset if your wallet allows for it.

I have heard a lot about virtual reality devices but never got a chance to experience what VR was and decided to give the Oculus Quest 2 a try.The device itself is nicely made but very intriguing. It is a pretty big unit that sits right in front of the eye, it is not too heavy but definitely carries some weight but is tightly secured thanks to the strap.The set up was quite easy as all I had to do was download an app on the phone which then communicate with the Oculus.I get motion sick very easily and was a bit worried I would not last long with the device but the library of apps and games is extensive and contains many options that are not zero gravity and are ground based.I started with the virtual visits of places around the world and I have to admit that it was an amazing experience as I felt that I was really visiting the country. I also tried a few games and it is definitely a huge difference over the console games I am used to as it really made me feel that I was inside the game.All in all, I have to say that I found the Oculus fantastic, I never thought that it would be this realistic.  I am glad I finally got a chance to own one and it goes with say that the Oculus Quest 2 gets a perfect rating from me.

I honestly didn't know if I'd even like VR, but the Oculus Quest 2 and the game Beat Saber (which you need to purchase separately) changed all that. I never thought of VR as an ideal place to get a workout. Beat Saber, which is a must purchase for the Oculus, gets my blood flowing and body sweating more than working out at the gym. The headset comes with an optional silicone covering which is very helpful as I can't believe just how much I sweat using this thing. I also purchased The Thrill of The Fight, which is one of the toughest and best boxing games i've ever played. Beyond games, I've enjoyed exploring VR worlds on AtlspaceVR, Facebook's Horizon's and VR Chat.I really like how the Oculus Quest 2 defines the playspace, there are options for both a fixed guardian and a custom guardian so you can define your play space. They also have the option of adding your couch and computer, so you can add both into your home VR Space.The Quest 2 has held up pretty well with one notable exception, the wrist straps aren't awesome. This can be easily remedied with an aftermarket controller wrap, which can add a much helpful ant-throw palm strap, which I greatly prefer.
review_title: I'm Surprised At How Much I Love The Oculus Quest 2

one_reviews_text: Pullitzer and Hearst never had anything like the total control Facebook and Twitter have over our entire society. Because you could choose to just not read the newspapers and you wouldn't have your real life family and friends pressuring you to read them and feeling personally rejected if you won't. That's power you can't buy. Speaking of things you can't buy, anyone who is banned from Facebook for political wrongthink because they made an effective argument that could have changed the course of an election against Facebook's preferred candidate can't buy the Oculus Quest 2 because a Facebook account is required. Automatic unconditional 1-star rating.

I bought this product to share with my nephew, after using it for about a month they got really hot and cold on fire and burned to the side of his face. They sent me a new one which was obviously refurbished. And now that they’ve merged with Facebook they’ve raised all of our passwords and email accounts and will no longer let you get on there regardless if you have your previous information or not. I said on the phone for four hours tonight trying to get this figured out and I got nowhere. I would buy a pair of binoculars and ducktape damn on my face and play Nintendo before I would go through again. I received nothing for my nephew getting burnt in my house almost catching on fire.
review_title: Thank I would rather jump ass first into a dildo factory then have to deal with these people!

one_reviews_text: First for Amazon…I actually bought this at Target so sorry you can’t verify my purchase.Now for the review…this system is a ton of fun and definitely worth trying just for the experience. It’s disorienting in a really fun way and you can cast what you are seeing to a tv for others to sort of participate.Set up was a problem for me. It would not detect Wi-Fi no matter what I tried. I looked online and found it was pretty common. I tried connecting with support but there was a crazy wait time. Luckily I found the factory reset and that fixed it, but I may have just returned it if that hadn’t worked.The battery lasts 2 hours which I thought would be fine, but you spend lots of time just looking around at different apps and handing the header back and forth with friends so the time flies by. We bought the elite head strap with battery for another 2 hours of game time but that added $100 to the cost. Definitely worth it, but anyone buying should expect they will likely need that as well.Before buying any games I would recommend playing free demos. There are not many out there but enough you can get a feel for what you like. Some games, like Creed, I didn’t like enough to buy, but playing in demo was a really cool experience that I would recommend everyone tries at least once.Lastly, the games are mostly around $30 so just be prepared that you will likely spend a couple hundred more than the initial $300 to get the accessories you want and the games you want.

If you have any problems good luck.  They have no phone number and it is impossible to get a supervisor.  I've sent 8 e-mails on an issue, opened two different cases with customer service, and all you get is the run around.  Until they fix there customer service issues - I'd recommend to stay away.

Don't buy Oculus! Get a vive or valve product. Facebook is an Advertisement based tech org. They historically have stopped supporting all their previous products when the upcoming release of the next product line is close. This is predatory! I have a Rift S that simply has a dented Display port end and I cannot get another cable. The entire system is useless and they wont sell me a simple cable. They want me to purchase a completely new product.Go with a vive, they still sell parts for their original product lines via a third party broker. Don't let Facebook corner you like they did me expecting that I purchase a new entire product instead of supporting the unit that is less than a year old.Also, if you are buying games, get it on Stream if you can. If you ever jump headset manufactures, you will still have access to your games on steam. If you buy from Oculus, they are no longer accessible once you jump brands.
review_title: Facebook/Oculus does not stand behind their product for long. No Parts available.

one_reviews_text:

 I guess don’t drink and do this 😂

I thought it was a gimmick, so I waited a long time to get into it, but truth be told - it's pretty unreal. Blew me away.It's good to know that if I'm every permanently disabled, or bedridden or something, that this thing exists. I can see myself rockin' out at 95 with one of these.A few points:-The VR game selection is a bit limited at this point, as the technology is still in it's infancy, relatively speaking. That said, there's still bound to be something that you'll like.- You can hook it up to a computer, and experience any of your games and programs on a virtual screen, in front of you. It's not much different from using your computer anyway, but it's good if you want to chill in a chair or something w/ your computer across the room. Get the cord, tho.- "Adult entertainment" has made it worth the price of admission, alone. I'm not kidding - this is next level stuff, here. Do yourself a favor and just grab a fleshlight, too. Dont forget the astroglide!In closing - it's well worth the 300 bucks.  I've experienced things that I never would have, before.The 128 gb has been fine for me, that's more than enough room to install whatever games. As far as entertainment goes, you can stream all of that. There is no reason to actually download movie content, and if you really want to have a backup of movie content, you can surf to the site on a PC and download it to a drive for safe keeping. Transfer it to your headset if you ever need it.Just do it

This is your gateway drug into the metaverse.  When you wear it replaces your real environment with an artificial one.  You draw a circle around yourself to create a safe area for you to move.  When you approach the boundary a virtual wall shows up.  If you cross it the real world replaces whatever you were doing.  It is extremely well-executed and necessary because you are entire, I debating using a lesser word than entirely but it fits, transported to somewhere else.  Even if the experience is lowres as some are the kinetic realism of immediate feedback to movement and how you move your body and head pull you in.  What you experience is total immersion in a generated environment.  The experience alone is like paying pong  40 years ago.  It was fun but mostly we all knew that pong was just a start and this was going to change the world. This is not pong, it is way past that, but the experience is so complete that while things are going to get better and better the overall encapsulation of your senses is already happening.  Until we just plugin, which is what this feels like except for the brick strapped to your face that in 5 years will be glasses or something more reasonable.  It's not hype and I feel old given how advanced this technology is and that I had no idea of what is going on.  You will need a better strap and a USB battery that has a type C connector to plug in the headset to extend it on time.  You probably have all that for your phone and other devices so the smallish battery on the unit is not a big deal.  I feel this is a mush have experience if you want to be up on where things are and will be.  I bought mine at Cosco because if Costco is selling this I know it is mainstream and I didn't even know it existed.  My mind is completely blown at this point.  If you live in a small space this will create a huge world in it, like the tents from Harry Potter that are small outside and enormous inside.  It feels like that.

I bought an oculus about 6 months ago, back in may the facebook email 2fa system started to not send emails. I have since been locked out of my oculus and facebook account with zero line of support.I no longer have access to my library and have to make a new account just to turn the thing into anything other than a paperweight. I have support tickets open since june that the most fruitful thing to come from it was an autogenerated message from facebook.Such a massive amount of money to waste because of garbage facebook security. I can only assume since during the pandemic IT companies production have improved for the most part and since it seems I can't get one real email from facebook in 4+ months I can only assume that Oculus + facebook is still ran by one douche in his garage. There is no customer support for Oculus. If you value your money avoid at all costs.
review_title: Never buy an Oculus, you WILL lose your money and games.

one_reviews_text: Just a very ho-hum thing.  Terrible ergonomics, horrible UX, incredibly low resolution (you will be distracted by literally seeing the pixel RGB components), horrible latency, very poor quality graphics if you don’t use a link with a decent PC (think like a not quite as good as an old Nintendo Wii), no rechargeable batteries in the controllers, no eye tracking, and on top of all of that you must have a Facebook account and share all your telemetry (read everything you do, all information that it’s cameras see, audio it processes, locations it’s used) with “meta”, and then have to pay additional through a store for the anemic VR offerings available.If you were a kid who liked to go up real close to your tv and see the separate RGB pixels then maybe you won’t mind being distracted by that with this, but that’s what you’ll see, it is not a sharp hi-res experience the actual separate RGB pixels though are distracting as anything to me, I can’t really se the image through the when it’s this low res.  Sadly this is an area that I had expected to improve since SIGGRAPH 15 years ago.  It hasn’t.The refresh rate and general latency/lag is also horribly nauseating, it seems that the screen refreshes at a higher rate but still has flicker at the edges of your eyes.  Like being under fluorescent light constantly, maybe it’s the LED refresh rate in combo with the screen, but it’s bad.  The tracking seems to be running at a different refresh rate too, you can really see it in the setup moments where you get to see the camera output.  It looks like maybe it’s refreshing at 15fps.  Either way it explains the very high latency.The fact that it can’t eye track means it can’t focus track either.  So everything in all the games is in focus at all depths.  Not so great but also every other aspect related to the eyes is bad.  The adjustments (3 positions only) manage to not quite fit anyone, the field of view is like looking through 2x lenses, focal plane is painful and convergence is so bad that it’s like doing those awful stereograms that were a hit in the 90s where you have to cross your eyes to see anything.  A few minutes of playing with this and once you take it off you’ll feel very messed up for half an hour or more.  I can only imagine the damage it’s doing to peoples eyesight.Outside of the core element being really incredibly poorly done the rest is nasty too.  This weighs down on your face, specifically you feel it tugging and pulling down on your cheeks of all things!  It’s not that lightweight, better than the ones in the 90s but not by that much.  There’s gapping around the nose area letting in light for me, the straps when lose make things worse and when tighter are just plain uncomfortable.  The padding around the face is no-where near enough for comfort, you feel it digging in, adding the optional rubber cover makes it irritate your skin.  The balance is very poor they could have brought a lot of the weight closer in, and honestly ditched most (all) of the onboard processing, they just want you locked in to their ecosystem.Speaking of there’s no way to use this without registering via Facebook.  The hell that is Web 3.0 and a lack of online compartmentalizing your life rears it’s ugly head again in the name of “consumer convenience”.  There is nothing here that you would want to share with Facebook (meta), nor should be forced to.  You basically feel violated the whole time using it and far less inclined to do darn thing with it, not that the experience doesn’t already dissuade.I honestly am having a hard time finding something positive to say about this mediocre product.  Maybe beat saber is mildly amusing for 20 minutes or so.  But that gets old fast.  It’s very uncomfortable and fatiguing (not to mention nauseating) to wear for longer periods, thankfully the batteries are eaten up fast which will stop you from extended sessions unless you use the link to keep it powered on but then you have cables.The only reason I have this thing is for software development because that’s what companies want right now.  Despite every developer I know being absolutely uninspired and depressed as hell about having to work on this pointless series of products the next generation of which will be ever more horrific violations of your privacy and moral code than you can currently imagine in the name of seizing control over the nascent NFT market by large corporations (that’s the direction in app transactions are going in already, which is the whole point of the metaverse, see PS Home and Second life for the templates of this, as well as the presentations by various tech bro CEOs, trust you will feel pressured into trying to get on that gold rush early so you too can be a millionaire from owning emperors new clothes, it’s cynical as anything), and making a more fancy but in practical use miserable privacy invading version of zoom.  So yeah, sorry guys I won’t be making the world a better place (quite the opposite), but I will be making bank off this junk.The price is good, it’s heavily subsidized by FB to get you in.  But the components aren’t great.

 I’ve had a lot of fun with this device. I really think it’s the best vr experience you can get especially for the price. I have looooved beat saber, job simulator, and super hot. Any game we get on here is a lot of fun. However I also don’t like it needed a Facebook account to set it up and if you get banned from Facebook you loose all your games. Luckily I haven’t done anything to get banned on Facebook but that doesn’t really seem fair, and that’s part of the reason people are against this push for all digital and no physical copies of games because you never truly own the digital games. Also oMeta is a creepy company and I don’t really enjoy being a user. I think changing the name from oculus quest to meta quest was a bad marketing decision and I’m never going to stop calling it oculus. Anyways though this thing has made me get my much needed exercise and realize I actually love brown a lot!!
review_title: Really really good but I hate Meta Still

one_reviews_text: This is the second time I've bought an Oculus headset.  I sold the first, and now I remember why I did with this second one.  It is amazing at first.  The technology works very well, and it's a surreal experience.But once you've played with it for a week or so, it get's very boring.  The content is low grade video games, and the resolution is not very good.  The headset is heavy and hurts your face.  The people you interact with inside are mostly children and nerdy adults.  Lots of time being wasted, and ultimately you realize you're waisting precious hours of your life that you could be using to do real things in the real world, which far surpasses any digital nonsense going on in the Oculus and Zuckerberg's deranged dream of a virtual world.Save your money and buy a surfboard or something.
review_title: Very cool at first, but boring very quickly

one_reviews_text: I bought this in January after reading an article in the NY Times about a cool new workout app.  I figured, what the heck, I like tech and could afford to lose a few pounds, so let's give this a try. Now, after having 3 defective devices (and waiting 2 months for a 4th), I honestly wish I could just get my money back.  It's not worth the headache of having to deal with their customer service.  My most recent headset (my 3rd one!) died in less than a week.  I had to wait a month for them to "authorize" the return and then had to wait another month to get them to actually ship a replacement.  Granted, this is THIRD TIME it has broken, so I'm a bit more than frustrated that it's been broken more than it's been working for the 10 months I've owned it.  Oh but wait, now they sent me the 4th one, and guess what?  It's missing controllers.  And a charger.  Thanks Oculus!  Well done!  Can I get my money back now please?
review_title: Do you like buggy tech and bad customer service? Then this is the product for you.

one_reviews_text: This product is a brick unless you have a Facebook (Meta, whatever) account, and will become a brick once more if you lose access to your Facebook account (or if it is banned, blocked, deleted, etc.). Historically, Facebook has done this for reasons like not using your real name, so you can't just make a "burner" account for Oculus purposes.

I bought this and then bought a painting app, etc. I was very happy with it but then my Facebook account was hacked and now my Oculus has become a expensive piece of nothing.  I will have to reset it and lose all my purchases. Facebook has zero support and the Oculus website sends you to FB. Urghh  The hacker has changed everything, even the ID.  The Oculus should be a stand alone account. Not shared FB account. A lot of people seem to be having this problem.

Have to set up Guardian every time I turn it on because it can't remember me drawing the area the last 100 times I drew it.I had the Rift S and "upgraded" to the Quest 2 because it listed as having a better resolution while being wireless.  That turns out to be completely false.  It's resolution is crap unless you use the link cable and run it as a Rift, which makes it almost as good as the Rift, but still worse than the Rift S and not wireless.If your face is shaped like a chimpanzee's, you'll find it to fit well, otherwise, there will be a huge gap right below your eyes even with the strap tight enough to leave marks on your head.It constantly crashes, displays a black screen, while playing or browsing menus.  I do not know why, my Rift S never did anything like that.If you wonder why other makers VR sets are twice the price, there's a reason.  Oculus is dollar store quality with the added benefit of Facebook anti-privacy.  Don't waste your time, I've done that for you, get an HTC.  I did get the Cosmos, works great, fits great.
review_title: Poor resolution and constant crashes, never remembers settings.

one_reviews_text: I love new technologies and it's been awhile since I've been watching VR tech.I've tried the original Quest from a friend and I was impressed with the immersive experience you get whether you're watching or gaming.Now with this Quest 2, the resolution is simply much better magnifying the immersive experience one gets on a VR headsetSetupI'm wearing a glass but I found that I don't need to wear one to use the Quest 2. My friend who wears a glass said it's still comfy to him while wearing the set.Initial setup is pretty easy. The 2 controllers are already connected and it asks to adjust the lens as needed.Account sign on - Many people (including me) are turned off of the way Oculus requires an FB account to log in. For me and I think for most, it's a privacy issue and FB is not that known to be an advocate of that. What I did, is I created a separate fresh FB account and that's what I used to log in to Quest 2. So far so good.Here's my favorite games that I play: • Super Hot • Beat Saber • Eleven Table Tennis • Vader Immortal 1-3I occasionally browse youtube VR contents, watch Netflix, HBO Max moviesWatching Youtube in VR is a different level of experience.Optionally, you have an option to connect this to a VR-ready PC to take advantage of the vast PCVR games only available to PCs.This allows you to play much more selection of games via PC. There are 2 ways to connect, one is wired via Oculus Link cable (purchased separately) and another is wirelessly through Virtual Desktop app from Oculus store. There's a number of sites discussing the how and the requirements, just google or search Youtube.I'm able to play Star Wars Squadrons, Half Life: Alyx, Powerbeats.In case you're not aware of the news that some users reported having a rash, the box already came with Quest 2 silicone cover. I've read in the news that the incidents only happen to a very small percentage and I personally have no issue using the default face plate and I've used it for like 30mins or so per session.In my opinion, it's kinda icky to use the default face plate if you're trying to use it for extended sessions especially with games like BeatSaber or Powerbeats where you'll be sweating a lot. The default one is made of I think high quality foam that can absorb sweat. I end up using the included rubber face plate that's easy to wipe with water/alcohol every after session for better hygiene.Mixed reality VRI've discovered this awesome feature just recently. It means you can put yourself inside a game and it doesn't need a green screen! There are more and more games being added. You can search Liv and mixed reality in Youtube for the how to videos.Overall I'm happy with Oculus Quest 2. Technologies change every time and I think it's the right time to jump on experiencing VR whether for workout, gaming, watching movies, explore different places virtually. Life is short. The immersive experience is just worth it. =)

This is a great buy for a stand alone vr system. No need for trackers, not even for a computer. You can use the vr’s storage to download games to your device and play without needing to connect to your computer.That said, make sure you buy the one with Enough storage for your needs! Airlink absolutely sucks… Do some research into your connection and router, to determine if it would work properly for you. In our case it’s super laggy and unplayable, so we’d need to buy an 80$ cable, get a separate router for internet dedicated just to the oculus etc. Not going to happen, so we download our games instead to the device.The headstrap is not very comfortable, so you will want to eventually upgrade. Again, don’t get sucked into buying the elite strap, plenty of people will tell you they will break fast. Save your money, join oculus Facebook groups and look for real experiences with the different options of straps before you decide on one.The headset is a bit top heavy with the original strap, my kids found that putting a tshirt under it before putting it on, helps the discomfort…I would recommend getting an extra battery, it does die pretty fast (especially if shared between 2 people).Otherwise, great buy. Gets you moving, it’s fun and easy to set up. Make sure you have a Facebook account.
review_title: Stand alone vr, but airlink not so good

one_reviews_text: I have been using a HP Reverb G1 for a while and it is fantastic.  However, I think I may have found a solid replacement.  Clarity is similar, but I believe the Reverb is probably slightly better, but it is too close to be sure.  What has really surprised me is the temperature of this headset.  I was expecting the battery powered display to better hotter than the Reverb, but it is actually much cooler.  My first headset was a Rift and I sold it immediately because it was too hot.  Then I bought a Samsung Odyssey and it was a little better and ultimately settle in with the Reverb which gets warm but is bearable.  I was shocked when I put this on and realized it was cooler than than previous headsets even though it has an active processor and battery.  My main reason for buying this was to see if it was a good solution for wireless VR and I can confirm that AirLink works perfectly with Steam VR.  I did buy a better facial interface and an AMVR TPU back pad to help distribute the pressure of the strap and I really like no longer having a bulky piece of plastic behind my head.  I can lean back and it feels soft when I hit my head against the back of my chair.  Lastly, I have to give FB credit, even though I hate them in general, I was able to walk into Best Buy and pick this up for $299.  Having a product at a good price and in stock is definitely an accomplishment in 2021.  I can't think of any reason not buy this if you want to try VR.  It is a pretty cool experience even if you are trading the crispness of a PC Monitor for a somewhat blurred view, you gain much more depth and control of your view.  I think both 2D and 3D have a place in my gaming library.  Games like Elite Dangerous are perfect for VR while other games are better suited for high definition displays.  I definitely recommend giving it a try.

Its really really fun.  Tough to get set up because you need a facebook account to get an oculus account to get the occulus app to get the...next...next...next.  But, once it is going, its addictive, unless it makes you motion sick, which is very possible.  I was blown away by the graphics, expecting pixelated stuff from years ago, but nope.  I got the VR Hot game, and its a good workout, just make room so you dont accidentally punch people.  The game Moss was amazing, kinda short, but great and you can play it sitting down.  For the kids, Acron!  OMG its so fun.  Because the littel kids hands cant reach all the triggers at once, most games are difficult, but Acron only needs the one trigger button, so we all take turns, and it is co-op with everyone else who can use the cell phone or tablet app.  If you have kids 6 and up, I strongly suggest that one.  Battery life is pretty good, but get a back up stand alone battery for long runs if you dont want to be tethered to the charger.  Fits nice and feels good on the head.  Dont use the rubber 'eyeglasses' thing unless you need to, it locks in moisture and can fog things up and heat them up.  All in all, efverything you need is in the nice box, you can even store it in there, its that nice.  Im really happy with this.  We play at least once a week. And yes, you can cast to most devices so people can watch what you are seeing.
review_title: Great but needs Facebook, tough for little hands

one_reviews_text: I really enjoyed and still am playing with the oculus, specially with high res latest content but FB (meta) track record is not promising▶ Quality & DesignNice slice white finish, really well made and surprisingly light. The remotes are also ergonomically made and compliment the design of the headset. The straps on the head set are comfortable and easy to adjust▶ SetupAs you probably aware you will need a FB account. It's pretty useless without one, so if you get kicked out or banned from FB and unable to come back you get yourself a nice piece of nothingness... isn't that greatOn the other hand the setup was pretty seamless and fairly quick. The tutorial is helpful to get the know the system and its limitations. It's nice that you can set a safe zone in your view so you wont hit any furniture or other obstacles▶ UsageHigh res stuff look pretty awesome and you probably won't get dizzy or nausea but lower res content is no fun and motion will hit your head and limit your usage as you quickly get disorientated. The remotes are very responsive and the tracking and visualization on your headset works great with minimal lag✅ Pros: Newer content, comfortable, easy to use❌ Cons: Fb account needed, lots of old lower res contentOverall, if you don't mind been bound to FB this is a really great piece to technology
review_title: Really amazing device but FB entanglement is questionable

one_reviews_text: Appearance:Sleek headset that can adjust to your head size.  The handheld wands  blend with the appearance of the headset.Assembly:This is plug and play.  Take it out of the box and start exploring!Installation:Only downside is that you have to use a Facebook account to log onto the Quest 2.  That is the only way this will work.  You'll also get a good number of software/firmware updates for the unit, so be prepared to wait a little bit after turning it on for the first time.  It is worth the wait though!  Pull on the headset, adjust the straps to your liking and adjust the lenses to move slightly in or out depending on how your eyes are positioned on your face.Thoughts:Man, this thing is awesome!  The graphics are fantastic and you can truly get lost in the environments.  Even the Oculus lobby is breathtaking.  Software setup is super easy.  You set your physical playzone up and the headset will track how close or how far you are from the edges.  There is also passthrough which will allow you to see the physical space in front of you, albeit from an alternate universe-type view.It's a fantastic piece for gaming, exploring (check out the ISS from the inside!), and almost anything else you can think of.  Personally, we play a lot of Beat Saber in this and it is just so much fun.  The games are fairly simple to browse, the app store could use some user experience work, but it's definitely good enough.It does get a bit warm inside the face area, so if you're playing a very physical game, be prepared for some sweat.  It might be a good idea to invest in a face mask protector so the foam portion isn't getting all wet.Overall:I love this system.  I would happily buy it again
review_title: Yes! Fun and Exciting VR Environment!

one_reviews_text: We were thinking of getting of getting a vr headset for gaming, but vr has to have you to have a facebook acount.  We know that facebook spys and plus, they can ban you from facebook anytime.I am 11 years old.
review_title: Grandma says NO just because Facebook is required.

one_reviews_text: I want to start with the issue I had with the store. Before I got this headset, I had an Oculus Rift (original generation) and in the PC store, I purchased multiple games. When I got this headset, I thought that those purchases would transfer over, but unfortunately, I was mistaken. It turns out that certain games require you to re-purchase games for the Quest store, even if you already bought them through the Rift store. Now, I was informed that developers need to specifically engineer their game to the lower-performance platform, but as a consumer, it doesn't feel good to have to re-buy a game just because it's on a different platform. I thought they would at least offer a discount on the game if it was already purchased through the other store, but apparently not. There is a way around this by using the Quest Link (or Air Link) to basically play off the PC you would usually use but with the upgraded headset and inside-out tracking, which is what I ended up using for games I had already purchased on Rift.Store issues aside, this headset is so much better than VR used to be in the early days. The ability to play without wires or backpack PCs is amazing and it's hard to imagine going back! Especially with the workout apps, or full-room movement apps, no wires is the only way to play and feel fully immersed. The screen-door effect is also very reduced when compared to the Rift.
